alcohol.name: Nut Brown Ale
alcohol.untappdString: Nut Brown Ale (Samuel Smith's Old Brewery)
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-samuelSmithsNutBrown.jpg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Brewed at Samuel Smith's small, traditional British brewery with well water (the original well sunk in 1758 is still in use), best barley malt, roasted barley, yeast and aromatic hops. Nut Brown Ale is relatively dry with a rich amber-brown color and nutty flavor derived exclusively from small amounts of dark malt. Brown ales are a specialty of northern England. Fermented in 'stone Yorkshire squares'.

# What you should know

The specific well water in Yorkshire, England helps form the base of this traditional brew. Samuel Smith's "Taddy" brewery is also one of the few that uses the Yorkshire Square method of brewing, which actually separates the wort (the boiled malt) from yeasty foam at the top. Periodically, some of the wort is pumped up into the yeast to feed it. Finally, the wort is drained, leaving the yeast behind, and a fairly bitter wort. Fortunately, there is enough residual yeast to stay back and continue to soften the taste. It's a laborious method, but it seems to work for Samuel Smith's

# The Boys' Take

We love our English traditional style beers and Sam Smith's Nut Brown is a perfect example of the style. malty, smooth, toasty flavors, and a medium plus body is perfect for a fall evening!

# About the Brewer

The original brewery that Samuel Smith started from started in 1758, although it wasn't until a couple of generations has passed when the true brewery started operations in 1847. Shortly after, old Samuel developed his yeast strain, and the brewery still uses it today- one of the longest continuous yeast strains there are. Plus, they still deliver their beer using horses (well, around Yorkshire, at least). There's also a line of over 300 pubs run by Samuel Smith's throughout England. So different, indeed.

# Drink if you Like

English-style, understated dark beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Tradition, horses, buggies, Yorkshire pudding

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a pint at the pub

# Pair With

Meat and potatoes, chocolate

alcohol.name: Black
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-Black_6539.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Allagash Black, our new Belgian style stout, is brewed with German 2 row barley, Torrified wheat and oats, balanced by a large addition of Belgian dark candi to give the Black a full and silky mouthfeel. Roasted malts give this stout its classic chocolate, toast and malty taste, and contribute to chocolate notes and a hint of roasted coffee in the aroma. The Black is fermented with a Belgian yeast strain and refermented in the bottle with the methode champenoise to make this beer truly unique

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Beer Description

Allagash Saison is our interpretation of a classic Belgian farmhouse style. It is a golden hued beer, brewed with a 2-Row blend, malted rye, oats and dark Belgian candi sugar. It was hopped with Tettnang, Bravo and Cascade hops. Fermented with a traditional saison yeast strain, this beer exhibits notes of spice and tropical fruit in the aroma. Citrus and a peppery spice dominate the flavor and make way for a pleasant malts

# What You Should Know

What is a Saison? Well, moyens de Saison en français\* (what Saison means in French) is "season", and Saisons were originally brewed in Belgium on farms for summer drinking. The beer would be brewed in the fall or winter to employ unoccupied farm workers and provide beer for seasonal laborers in the summer. Traditionally, these SaIsons would have strong yeast flavors but a crisp, light color. Originally, the Saisons would have had lower ABVs, in the 1900s the alcohol content started to creep up to 5%-7%. Today, there is great variety in what constitutes a Saison, but almost are extremely dry but still malty. Oh, and they are cool. Really cool. So there's that.

\*Note: this translation was definitely taken from Google Translate. Our apologies if makes no sense whatsoever.

# The Boys' Take

Man, Allagash sure does make good beer. This one is easy on the eyes (being a nice clear yellow) and in the mouth. It's gonna be dry, but very crisp and refreshing. Saisons can seem strange or confusing to the uninitiated, but don't be scared. They all (and especially this one) have a lot to offer!

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian beer, Pale ales, Wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Farmhouses, Belgium, a beer earned with manual labor

# Drink While You Are

On the farm, cooling off after a long day

# Pair With

Asian, Farmhouse Food, Red Meat, French Cuisine

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

This golden hued ale is marked by passion fruit and herbal notes in the aroma, with subtle suggestions of banana and honey surfacing from its deep and complex palate. The Tripel's finish is remarkably long and soothing.

# The Boys' Take

Man, Allagash sure does make good beer. This tripel has been held to the same high standards that Allagash has been known for since they first started brewing. If you like rich Belgian style beers with rich complexity and lighter body this is your brew!

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, Saisons.

# Ideal for People who Like

Things that come in 3's, Aperitifs

# Drink While You Are

Winding it down for the night, On your trip to Brussels

# Pair With

Limberger, Rochford, Brie, Camembert, Desserts with honey.

# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float

Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-10891_26699_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Most breweries have at least one piece of equipment that's just a bit persnickity. Here at Boulevard it's fermenter number seven, the black sheep of our cellar family. Ironically, when our brewers were developing variations on a traditional Belgian-style farmhouse ale, the perfect combination of elements came together in that very vessel. You could call it fate, but they called it Tank 7, and so it is. Beginning with a flavorful surge of fruity aromatics and hoppy, grapefruit notes (Amarillo hops), this complex, straw-colored ale finishes long, dry and spicy.

# The Boy's Take

A very traditional Belgian Saison with just a little extra floral hops, and grapefruit citrus notes. As with all the smokestack series this beer is premium in quality and another great traditional Belgian style brew from Boulevard.

# About the Brewer

Boulevard has been a fixture in Kansas City since 1989 and is now a household name in much of the Midwest. In fact, if you're in the Midwest, you won't be able to get away from the ubiquitous (and award-winning) Unfiltered Wheat Beer. Honestly, we think a lot of Boulevard's beers are very Midwestern: not as brash as the West Coast, not as scrappy as the East Coast- just high-quality and presented simply. And it seems to have worked. Founder John McDonald originally planned for 6000 barrels of beer a year in his business plan. Now, the capacity is over 600,000 barrels. I'd say that business plan worked. The two biggest sellers are Unfiltered Wheat and Boulevard Pale Ale, but we encourage you to venture to try a few others, like the Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale, the Double Wide IPA and the Saison-Brett

# Drink this if You Like

Wheat beers, yeasty and fruity beer, Hefeweizens

# Ideal for People who Like

Fairy tales, Midwestern values, Belgian (but not really, Dutch) values

# Drink While You Are

Making the best of a bad situation, making lemonade out of lemons.

# Pair With

Citrus summer salad, Salmon, Grilled chicken, Veggie Burger.

alcohol.name: Indian Brown Dark IPA
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-4013_42d21_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Drink this if You Like

Brown ales on the hoppier side, Pale Ales, Scotch Ales

# Beer Description

Forget about the car companies, this is the original hybrid. A cross between a Scotch Ale, an India Pale Ale and an American Brown, Indian Brown Ale is well-hopped and malty at the same time (It's magical!).The beer has characteristics of each style that inspired it: the color of an American Brown, the caramel notes of a Scotch Ale, and the hopping regimen of an India Pale Ale. We dry-hop the Indian Brown Ale in a similar fashion to our [60 Minute IPA](http://www.dogfish.com/brews-spirits/the-brews/year-round-brews/60-minute-ipa.htm) and [90 Minute IPA](http://www.dogfish.com/brews-spirits/the-brews/year-round-brews/90-minute-ipa.htm). This beer is brewed with Aromatic barley and organic brown sugar

# What you should know

What can brown do for you?

# The Boy's Take

It's not going to be as sweet as other brown ales you may have tried, and actually has more hints of chocolate and coffee than the caramel or nutty flavor of many brown ales. 

# About the Brewer

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role. Founder Sam Calagione started the brewery in Milton, DE in 1995 and now spends much time on television discussing the craft beer industry. In fact, at least on the east coast, it's hard to avoid DFH- there's a hotel, a tv show and even sausages for heaven's sake! But they do make amazing beer, often with unique flavor combinations and even stranger names. 90-Minute IPA is the more extreme version of one of Dogfish's signature brews (the 60-minute IPA).


# Ideal for People who Like

Indians and Bollywood, Hybirds, Mixtapes

# Drink While You Are

Being indecisive, looking for a little more kick in your Brown Ale

# Pair With

Balsamic vinaigrette, smoked meat, duck, game, prosciutto, stews

alcohol.name: Hazelnut Brown Nectar
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-4179_efa20_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Dark brown in color with a hazelnut aroma, a rich nutty flavor and a smooth malty finish. Hazelnut Brown Nectar Ale is a blend of Great Western 2-row Pale, Munich, Hugh Baird Brown, Crystal 80 and Crystal 135, Carastan, and Beeston Pale Chocolate malts; hazelnut extract; Perle and Saaz hops.

# What you should know

Sweet and roasty flavors from the Munich, Brown and Pale Chocolate malts mix with a couple of hops that are there just to add an edge of flavor at the end.

# The Boys' Take

Anyone up for Nutella? The hazelnut flavor in this guy brings a nice balance to the sweet malt.

# About the Brewer

All of craft beer has a little bit of revolutionary flavor to it. However, Rogue Brewing embraces rebellion as a way of life. The brewery started as a brewpub in Ashland, OR in 1988, but soon outgrew that space. That led to an expansion to Newport, OR and a partnership with local restaurateur Mohava Niemi. A bathtub picture of Niemi (or "Mo" as she is known) still occupies place of honor on the wall of Rogue Brewing. Rogue very consciously assumes a role as a voicepiece for craft brewers and think of themselves as leading a revolution, not just in beer but in thinking. It's tough to argue with the results of their dedicated approach. Rogue is prolific and you can find their beer all over the place. It seems like the revolution is winning. Besides the Dead Guy Ale, other favorites are the Chocolate Stout and the Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout.

# Drink this if You Like

Brown ales, porters, hazelnuts

# Ideal for People who Like

Nutella, toast, dessert

# Pair With

Gouda, BBQ, roasted pork, pecan pie, French onion soup

alcohol.name: Mocha Porter
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-MochaPorter_6863.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Ruddy brown in color, a bittersweet balance of malt and hops with a light cream finish. 12 Ingredients: 2-Row, Munich, C120, Chocolate, Black, Kiln Coffee & Rogue Farms Dare™ & Risk™ Malts; Rogue Farms Rebel™ & Liberty™ Hops; Free Range Coastal Water and Pacman yeast. 
"Let us give praise to our maker and glory to his bounty by learning about beer." - Friar Tuck

# What you should know

The Black, Chocolate and Coffee malts all build on the base of the standard malts to build a robust, roasted and dry flavor.    

# The Boys’ Take

This is like a strong cup of black coffee in the morning.  The flavor is all rich, dry, robust chocolate and coffee.  There’s a little bit of sweetness in there, but don’t get confused by the “mocha” label.  This one is dry.

# About the Brewer

All of craft beer has a little bit of revolutionary flavor to it.  However, Rogue Brewing embraces rebellion as a way of life.   The brewery started as a brewpub in Ashland, OR in 1988, but soon outgrew that space.  That led to an expansion to Newport, OR and a partnership with local restaurateur Mohava Niemi.  A bathtub picture of Niemi (or “Mo” as she is known) still occupies place of honor on the wall of Rogue Brewing.  Rogue very consciously assumes a role as a voicepiece for craft brewers and think of themselves as leading a revolution, not just in beer but in thinking.  It’s tough to argue with the results of their dedicated approach.  Rogue is prolific and you can find their beer all over the place.  It seems like the revolution is winning.  Besides the Dead Guy Ale, other favorites are the Chocolate Stout and the Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout.

# Drink this if You Like

Stouts, Porters, Black Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Black Coffee, Dark Chocolate, Burnt Toast

# Drink While You Are

Feeling brooding, Feeding your Darker Side

# Pair With

Beef, Dessert

IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Our India Pale Ale exhibits a complex hop aroma, largely due to the generous usage of Cascade and Centennial hops, as well as a subtle malt character from the various malts used to achieve the wonderful balance exhibited in a world-class IPA. San Diego has become world renown for the wonderful and flavorful beers produced here – and India Pale Ales are no exception. Our national award winning interpretation of the style reflects both the history of IPA and the American variation of this distinct beverage. We hope you enjoy it!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Imperial IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Award Winning beers, Wonder Bread

# Drink While You Are

Sitting down, Missioning

# Pair With

Traditional Mexican Fare, Grilled Meats

alcohol.name: Grapefruit Sculpin
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-285658_5908f_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The Sculpin IPA is a testament to our humble beginnings as Home Brew Mart. Founded in 1992, the Mart continues to be a catalyst for the San Diego brewing scene, setting the trend for handcrafted ales. Inspired by our customers, employees and brewers, the Sculpin IPA is bright with aromas of apricot, peach, mango and lemon. Its lighter body also brings out the crispness of the hops. This delicious Ballast Point Ale took a Bronze Medal at the 2007 Great American Beer Festival in the Pro Am category. The Sculpin fish has poisonous spikes on its fins that can give a strong sting. Ironically, the meat from a Sculpin is considered some of the most tasty. Something that has a sting but tastes great, sounds like a Ballast Point India Pale Ale. Our Grapefruit Sculpin is the latest take on our signature IPA. Some may say there are few ways to improve Sculpin’s unique flavor, but the tart freshness of grapefruit perfectly complements our IPA’s citrusy hop character. Grapefruit’s a winter fruit, but this easy-drinking ale tastes like summer.

# What you should know

This beer is hoppy, but doesn’t rely on brute force to bring across the delicious.  The use of lighter, soft malts (only four varieties) leads to a light body that really showcases the bright hop taste.  Unusually, hops are actually added during the mashing process, to give a nice oily feel and taste.

# The Boys' Take

There’s a reason a lot of people will say this is literally the best American IPA!  The hops are allowed free reign to really show themselves off, and there is so much flavor- mango, grapefruit, pine.  Treat this like Skittles.  Taste the rainbow.  

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers.  Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene.  Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world.  As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out.  Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born.   Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea.

# Drink this if You Like

Fruity or tropical IPAs, IPAs in general

# Ideal for People who Like

The tropics, fishing, the sunny climes of San Diego

# Drink While You Are

Enduring a brutal winter and wishing you were in San Diego, dealing with a hot summer and wishing you were in San Diego

# Pair With

Tropical savory foods (think flavored by coconut), Jerk Chicken, Tropical fruit

alcohol.name: Idiot IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Brewed with 8 different hops and dry hopped with
whole cone Cascades. Its more powerful than our Islander IPA and even
the most intelligent have become "idiot" after a few pints of this super
hopped up beer!

# The Boy’s Take

The Islander IPA swings for a tropical home run but
the idiot IPA takes it to a whole new level. A west coast hop bomb that
will not disappoint the hop heads out there!

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island
roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America’s
greatest beach (Coronado) and their first keg delivery was straight to
the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick
Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look
for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000
barrels a year, and we can’t wait for an ever-greater selection to be
available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit,
the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Drink this if You Like

West Coast IPAs, DIPAs, Imperial IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Acting the fool, living outside of social
norms

# Drink While You Are

Finding your beach, doing some California
Dreaming

# Food Pairings

Bacon Cheese Burgers, Spicy BBQ, Pad Thai

alcohol.name: Flesh & Blood IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description:  

An honest to goodness India Pale Ale brewed with a bevy of real citrus including orange peel, lemon flesh & blood orange juice.

# What you should know: 

Tropical fruit included as an ingredient in IPAs is sooooo the rage in 2016.  The sugars in the fruit provide extra food for the yeast but still stay around, no longer sweet but still flavorful.

# The Boys’ Take: 

If there’s a more refreshing summer beer, we’d like to hear it. Of course, tons of fruit and pith- it almost feels like there is grapefruit pulp in there.  And there are still hops, don’t worry

# About the Brewer:  

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role.  Founder Sam Calagione started the brewery in Milton, DE in 1995 and now spends much time on television discussing the craft beer industry.  In fact, at least on the east coast, it’s hard to avoid DFH- there’s a hotel, a tv show and even sausages for heaven’s sake!  But they do make amazing beer, often with unique flavor combinations and even stranger names.   90-Minute IPA is the more extreme version of one of Dogfish’s signature brews (the 60-minute IPA).  If you like this beer, try the 60-minute for session drinking or the Burton Baton for a full experience.

# Drink If you Like: 

IPAs, citrusy hops

# Ideal for People who Like:  

The number 60, egg timers, dogfish

# Drink While You Are: 

Trying your first IPA, going back to your craft beer roots 

# Pair With:  

Spicy, pesto, grilled salmon, soy sauce, pizza, aged cheddar

alcohol.name: Hipster Ale
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Perhaps you heard of a worldwide beer-movement
that tributes favorite hipster neighbourhoods across the globe. First
came Istedgade, Copenhagen then Södermalm, Stockholm followed by
Williamsburg, New York and Shoreditch, London accompanied by Trastevere,
Rome & last El Raval, Barcelona. If you feel excluded because you’re hip
but your city is not, this cutting-edge, ‘hip without borders’ pale ale
is an homage to you – the global hipster. Cheers!

# The Boys’ Take

Usually known for doing everything to the extreme,
Evil Twin has really toned it down with this really solid pale ale. With
a great balance of bready malts and floral and citrus hops this is a
great beer for any occasion. 

# About the Brewer

Evil Twin is unique. It’s a gypsy brewery, meaning
it develops the recipes, but uses breweries across the world to actually
make the beer. This means it isn’t committed to a solid list of beers
that it makes at its brewery. It bounces around from one to the another,
making a wide range of different special releases, along with a few that
they release year-round. Check out their website
([www.eviltwin.dk](http://www.eviltwin.dk)) - I mean, there are tons of
beers here. It’s made in the states, but marketed like an import (and
priced like it, too). Quite an interesting brewery. Low Life is brewed
in Connecticut, in case your were wondering. Check out their other beers
in the import aisle!

# Drink if You Like

IPAs, Pale Ales, West Coast Style IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Stuff that other people don’t think are
cool yet.

# Drink While You Are

Being ironic, wearing a scarf, being “unique”

# Pair With

Burgers, Buffalo wings, BBQ.

alcohol.name: Raging Bitch Belgian IPA
alcohol.untappdString: Raging Bitch Belgian IPA (Flying Dog Brewery)
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-5756_58e81_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The American IPA hoppines or Belgian funk of Raging Bitch can be brought out with food. Flavor notes: Sweet malt body contrasted with pine and grapefruit hop flavors and exotic fruit yeast notes.

# What you should know

Flying Dog's bottle art is by done by famous artist Ralph Steadman. The Gonzo art is most associated with the writing of Hunter S. Thompson.

# The Boy's Take

A well balanced IPA disguises its high ABV with a solid malt back bone that balances its hop profile.

# About the Brewer

Ok, so the Flying Dog guys from Maryland are a little off their rocker. They take the craft beer stereotypes to their extremes, with loud branding, double-entendre names and goofy titles. But look past the goofiness and you'll see a really high-quality brewer. The founder came up with the outrageous name of Flying Dog in Pakistan of all places. Originally a Colorado brewery, the beer is now made really close by in Frederick, MD.

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian Pale Ale's, Pale Ales, IPA's

# Ideal for People who Like

The bohemian writer lifestyle, dual citizenship.

# Drink While You Are

Wearing lederhosen, watching Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas, On an acid trip.

# Pair With

Wasabi ginger, jerk, Caju, or cayenne, tangy cheese with fruit, dark chocolate

alcohol.name: Imperial IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

This full bodied Imperial IPA is brewed with massive amounts of premium varieties of hops such as Amarillo, Cascade, Simcoe and Crystal and paired with a rich blend of luscious Munich, caramel and 2-row pale malts. The result is a perfect balance of luxuriant malt and heady, exhilarating hop flavor. After primary fermentation is finished, we dry hop our Imperial IPA with copious quantities of the above mentioned hops. It is then cold conditioned for a few weeks. The result is an outstanding and unforgettable hop aroma. Starting with an original gravity of 20 Plato and finishing at 8.0% alcohol by volume, this Imperial India Pale is a hop tour de force!

# What You Need to Know

Despite the lofty titles, this beer is brewed with mostly traditional techniques, including mid-bitterness hops, such as Amarillo, Cascade and Crystal. In fact, Crystal is a variant of traditional German hops. Dry-hopping is an old technique that involves adding hops after the boil, so that they are not heated enough to release alpha acids. That means hop flavor, but not bitterness.

# The Boy's Take

Very malty, Mendocino DIPA may actually remind you more of a barleywine, with a lot of flavors, but not necessarily the hop blast that you expect when you see the term "Imperial IPA"

# About the Brewer

Mendocino- brewer's brewers. There's no glitzy website and one Facebook post a week, but they've been focused on making great beer since 1983. It's literally the second brewery to open since Prohibition was repealed. The brewpub was duly opened off of Highway 101 north of San Francisco, and business took off- it was the only gig in town. Mendocino also has a strategic partnership with Olde Saratoga Brewing, giving it access to coast-to-coast distribution. But, here 32 years later, not much has changed. At Mendocino, it's about making beer. That's it.

# Drink this if You Like

Imperial IPAs, Barleywines

# Ideal for People who Like

Traditional recipes, the 101, Californians

# Drink While You Are

Pausing from a top-down road trip

# Pair With

Malty desserts, bacon cheeseburgers, thai food

alcohol.name: Simtra Triple IPA
alcohol.untappdString: Simtra Triple IPA (Knee Deep Brewing Company)
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-SimtraTrippleIPA_93848.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Simtra Triple IPA delivers a punch in the face with its very danky hop aroma derived from Simcoe and Citra hops. You wanted more hops you got them.

# The Boys' Take

A really hoppy brew from the masters of the IPA Knee Deep. This hop monster clocks in at 131 IBUs. If you're on the quest for an ever hoppier IPA this is the next rung on the ladder.

# About the Brewer

In the fall of 2010 while tasting some of their home brew Jeremy and Jerry Moore decided to get into the premium craft beer business and they wanted to go more than just "Knee Deep" in the market. They started with contract brewing their beer (having other breweries brew your beer in their facility. They currently have their own space and re cranking out some award winning IPAs.

# Drink If You Like

Double IPAs, IPAs, Imperial IPAs

# Ideal For People Who Like

Wading, Maniacal cartoons

# Drink While You Are

Fly fishing a California trout stream, Going the extra mile again.

# Food Pairings

Pad Thai, Red Thai Curry, Buffalo wings,

alcohol.name: IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Our India Pale Ale exhibits a complex hop aroma, largely due to the generous usage of Cascade and Centennial hops, as well as a subtle malt character from the various malts used to achieve the wonderful balance exhibited in a world-class IPA. San Diego has become world renown for the wonderful and flavorful beers produced here – and India Pale Ales are no exception. Our national award winning interpretation of the style reflects both the history of IPA and the American variation of this distinct beverage. We hope you enjoy it!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Imperial IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Award Winning beers, Wonder Bread

# Drink While You Are

Sitting down, Missioning

# Pair With

Traditional Mexican Fare, Grilled Meats

alcohol.name: Shipwrecked
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

A style of beer curiously born on the foggy shores
of Father Junipero Serra’s first founding mission. Our own vigorous
entry is one rebellious IPA, quick on the trigger, and brimming with a
bounty of hop ingenuity. This is a big, bold, brazen beer, a restless
vision of a new America.

# The Boy’s Take

This is a very west coasty double IPA. Plenty of
hops and malt perfectly blending malt sweetness and citrusy goodness. If
you haven’t tried this one you’re in for a treat!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each. We recommend the
Dark Seas Imperial Stout and also their Pils and Helles lagers.

# Drink this if You Like

Double IPAs, Imperial IPA, IPA

# Ideal for People who Like

Shipwrecks, architecture

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying 24/7 sun, sailing the open seas,
channeling your inner conquistador

# Pair With

Chimichangas, Pad Thai, Mango Chutney.

alcohol.name: Brutal India Pale Ale
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-515064_80a73_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Brutal combines Oregon hops with English Malts. The Oregon grown Crystal hop is a triploid variety developed from the German Hallertau aroma hop variety with contributions from Cascade, Brewers Gold, and Early Green. Crystal is the only hop used in brewing Brutal and it provides a massive amount of aroma without dry-hopping. The English malts used are floor malted Pipkin (a mellow cross of Maris Otter and Warboys, from an English company called Beeston), Cara Vienna and Cara Wheat.

# What you should know

Rogue has acres of their own proprietary hop farms where they have developed several varieties just for their beers. The Crystal hops here create a unique flavor that is still mostly floral and earthy.

# The Boys' Take

Brewed especially for those crazy hop heads in Rogue Nation, Brutal IPA is still a well-balanced IPA. Malt still leads the way, but the get ready for really serious hop flavor that starts in the middle and goes all the way through for a long, bitter finish.

# About the Brewer

All of craft beer has a little bit of revolutionary flavor to it. However, Rogue Brewing embraces rebellion as a way of life. The brewery started as a brewpub in Ashland, OR in 1988, but soon outgrew that space. That led to an expansion to Newport, OR and a partnership with local restaurateur Mohava Niemi. A bathtub picture of Niemi (or "Mo" as she is known) still occupies place of honor on the wall of Rogue Brewing. Rogue very consciously assumes a role as a voicepiece for craft brewers and think of themselves as leading a revolution, not just in beer but in thinking. It's tough to argue with the results of their dedicated approach. Rogue is prolific and you can find their beer all over the place. It seems like the revolution is winning. Besides the Dead Guy Ale, other favorites are the Chocolate Stout and the Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, hops

# Ideal for People who Like

Fan clubs, tough guys and hop heads

# Drink While You Are

Feeling like a fan boy, drinking an IPA just for you

# Pair With

Seafood, beef

alcohol.name: Stone Ruination Double IPA 2.0
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-1044097_0165f_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

So called because of the immediate ruinous effect on your palate. Bracingly bitter. Thick, pungent hop aroma. We would say that no hops were injured in the brewing of this beer, but that would be a massive lie. In fact, the words "Stone Ruination IPA" are what older hop vines use to cause little hop vines to quiver with fright and lose sleep at night. We at Stone honor the brutal massacre of countless hops with this "Liquid Poem to the Glory of the Hop!" Paganism at its best!

# What You Should Know

Stone created this IPA out of their original anniversary IPA and doubled it 5 times (that's 32 times for you math majors), until they couldn't squeeze any more hops into their brew.

# The Boy's Take

Despite all the hoppiness, this beer is surprisingly smooth. But you'll still get resiny, taste that you're looking for.

# About the Brewer

Stone, located in Escondido, CA, is brash, fun, and serious about beer. Co-founders Greg Koch and Steve Wagner met in 1989 and quickly discovered they both loved brewing. Not so quickly, they decided to open a brewery. Greg was the business man, Steve the brewmaster. They brewed beers that define the West Coast style- adventurous and hop-forward. They released the Arrogant Bastard strong ale (a revolution at the time) and quickly grew a reputation for not being afraid to stand up to the big guys. Along the way, they've become pretty big themselves, now being available almost everywhere. In fact, Stone is one of the top 5000 fastest-growing private companies in the US… and has been for 10 straight years. The icing on the cake? Stone became the first craft brewery to stake its flag in the heard of the beer universe- Germany. Just this year, they announced that they will be opening a brewery in Berlin. Woah.

# Drink this if You Like

Lots and lots of hops

# Ideal for People who Like

Taking things to the max, anniversaries, and oh yeah, hops

# Drink While You Are

Finding yourself gnawing on pine limbs instead of drinking beer

# Pair With

It had better be spicy!

# Beer Description

A truly authentic Belgian style wheat or "white" ale, this Rascal is unfiltered (yup, that's yeast on the bottom) and cleverly spiced with coriander and Curacao orange peel producing a refreshingly fruity thirst quencher.

# What you should know

Witbiers (from the Belgian word for "white") are one of the most traditional Belgian styles, and didn't begin to become popular in the US until the introduction of Blue Moon (by Miller Coors, ironically) in the early 2000s. The Curacao orange hails from the island of the same name (actually a part of the Dutch kingdom) and its peel has been used in the last century to spice up Belgian whites. This variety of orange is actually way too bitter to eat, but the pungency of its peel makes for a great counter-balance to the soft, wheat-y malt of the beer.

# The Boys' Take

This is soft and citrusy and a little heavier than some other white beers. This is what we would say is just pleasant to drink- almost velvet in the mouth and sweet to the tongue.

# About the Brewer

Adam Avery started Avery Brewery in 1993 in Boulder, CO. It was bold at the time to open a brewery, and Avery started small. However, now today is established solidly as a quality brewer out of the brewery mecca of Denver/Boulder. Avery is committed to making original beer… and not just what everybody wants. This means that it hasn't had the same commercial success, but also means it gets to keep a solid reputation with the experts. Some of the best aggressive beers come from here- especially the seasonal Dictator series- which contains traditional classic styles on steroids. If like a drop-kick to the face of fresh hops in the springtime, check out The Maharaja- an Imperial IPA.

# Drink this if You Like

Unfiltered beer, Belgians, wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Citrusy drinks, comfort-down mattresses, playful devils

# Drink While You Are

Kicking back with an orange slice, up to some minor mischief

# Pair With

Spicy food such as thai or Mexican, blackened fish, ceviche

Passion Fruit Kicker
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-1130373_1cb25_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

We’ve kicked it up a notch by adding a tropical twist to this refreshing ale. Get amped on Passion Fruit Kicker—a jaw-dropping, mouth-watering, smooth brew with sweet, tart, fruity flavor. We layer passion fruit tea and passion fruit juice with wheat malt and 2-row malted barley to bring you this exhilarating crowd pleaser. Your palate will do a 360 for more of this luscious wheat ale. Appearance—Hazy pale yellow with white beer foam. Aroma—Passion fruit pungency and fruit Belgian yeast esters similar to bubblegum. Flavor—Flavor has a prominent sweet tart passion fruit character that mingles with the Belgian fruit bowl esters. Note: This is different than the previous beer under this name which was a higher gravity ipa with brett blended with a wine barrel aged beer.

# The Boys’ Take

Light and crisp with just a hint of passion fuit zip. It’s the perfect summer brew if you’re looking for something just a little different!

# About the Brewer

Husband and wife team Mike and Lisa Hinkley lead Green Flash, and have since starting the brewery in 2002.  Located in San Diego, they were one of the pioneers of the “west coast” style which has led to an explosion of flavor and aggression in San Diego and San Francisco (and now LA!).  In many ways, Green Flash (along with Stone and Lagunitas) is responsible for the flavor revolution.  So that’s that.  Nowadays, Green Flash continues to make quality, mostly hop-forward beers, included some like the Palate Wrecker and the Green Bullet Triple IPA (not even sure what that means!)

# Drink this if You Like

Wheats, Wits, Whites, Golden Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

A new twist on an original, Passion Fuit

# Drink While You Are 

Playing Poker, On a tropical island

# Pair With

Citrus Salad, Grilled Chicken, Grilled Pork chops with mango chutney.

alcohol.name: Fireside Chat
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-7468_b8213_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Like FDR's Depression-Era Radio Addresses, which were like a kick in the butt and a hug at the same time, our Fireside Chat is a subtle twist on the traditional seasonal brew. We begin with a rich, dark, English-style ale and then we improvise with spices until we know we have a beer worth sharing with the nation. Celebrating the right to be original.

# What You Should Know

Winter warmers are generally characterized by big malt flavor, and a wide variety of spices (more a feature of American interpretations rather than the original English style). They also typically carry higher alcohol content. Fireside Chat is brewed with a delicious medley of spices and also cocoa nibs to give a slight chocolate flavor.

# The Boys' Take

Ask Zach about this beer, and he'll tell you it's dope! An office favorite, Fireside Chat is rich, but without being overpowering and the mix of spices is just delightful.

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious. They just have the advantage of pulling it off maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

Dark ales, Winter warmers, Strong ales

# Ideal for People who Like

World War II, Christmas spices, mulled cider, a cozy blanket

# Drink While You Are

Wanting to be Zach's friend, listening to the radio

# Pair With

An aperitif, dessert

# Beer Description

Abita Turbodog is a dark brown ale brewed with Willamette hops and a combination of British pale, crystal and chocolate malts. This combination gives Turbodog its rich body and color and a sweet chocolate-toffee like flavor.

# What you Need to Know

The Turbodog was actually originally released as a special brew, but popular response was so positive Abita decided to keep it around full-time

# The Boy's Take

(In slow jam voice) This one's smooooth baby.   The taste you' re going to get here is almost entirely malts, and those malts roll nicely on the tongue.    It ' s not super sweet, just the taste of delicious barley.

# About the Brewer

Abita was founded in 1986, and is in many ways the quintessential Southern beer.  Brewed in Abita Springs, LA (40 minutes north of New Orleans), Abita makes a wide range of brews, some of which are perfect for pairing with seersucker and sticky nights- and that's something we need here in the South.  Another added benefit is the pure, deep water from Abita Springs- this is the last little bit that kicks Abita beer "up a notch!"  Most Abita beers are light drinking and perfect for summer nights, and are made with all-natural, high-quality ingredients.

# Drink this if You Like

Brown ales, Porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Jambalaya, Brits at Mardi Gras, Dogs with Jetpacks

# Drinking While you Are

Seducing someone (we have been watching a lot of The Americans recently although no, they don't usually use beer to seduce their victims)

# Pair with

Meat generally, sausage, smoked fish, as a marinade or braise, chocolate

alcohol.name: Turbodog

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

A medium-bodied pale ale with a beautiful copper color, a robust head, and the rich flavor of caramel malt.

# What you should know

Boontling is a language used on every Anderson Valley Brewing labels. Spoken by the inhabitants of the Anderson Valley, of which Boonville is the largest town. Boonville was an isolated farming and logging town during the late 1800's. There are a couple different stories about the origin of Boontling. Some say that the language was created by the women, children, and young men in the hop fields and farmlands as a means of entertainment, and that it spread through the region as the kids continued using it when they grew up.

# The Boy's Take

Amber ales are one of those beer styles it's hard to do wrong but Anderson Valley true to form has produced one of the best Amber Ale's around! Not too heavy with caramel maltiness and just a hint of floral hops. A prefect easy drinker.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Red Ales, Amber Lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

Small towns, Local lingo

# Drink While You Are

Finishing up a meditation sesh, looking at something beautiful

# Pair With

Anything off the grill, Pork tenderloin, grilled chicken, burgers.

alcohol.name: Boont Amber Ale
California Amber
alcohol.untappdString: Calico Amber Ale (Ballast Point Brewing & Spirits)
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

A rich, copper ale with a case full of gold medals. Our Calico Amber Ale takes its inspiration from traditional English ESBs. Four types of malts give it a bold complexity, and our proprietary yeast strain lends it a fruity, madeira-like richness. However, it’s the American hops that give this ale a distinct bite and floral aroma that have earned it just about every major beer medal.

# The Boys' Take

If you’re an amber ale drinker this might be a little more then you bargained for. If you love an IPA but are looking for something a little meltier this is your beer. A traditional amber ale with the hops of an IPA and the beautiful amber complexion of an easier drinker it doesn’t get much more balanced than this! 

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers.  Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene.  Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world.  As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out.  Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born.   Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea.

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Pale Ales, IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Coronado, Something a little bit extra.

# Drink While You Are

Eating sushi, resting after kiteboarding

# Pair With

Sweet Hawaiian fish, mango chutney burger, Hawaiian BBQ.

alcohol.name: Evil Twin
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description:  

This blood-red ale may not be what you might expect from a malty and hoppy craft beer. Evil Twin has a rich malt character, without being overly sweet. It has a huge hop character, without being overly bitter. It is a great example of a bold, rich, balanced craft beer, without being heavy and hard to drink in quantity. Our Evil Twin is only bad because it is too good to resist.

# The Boy’s Take: 

You’d think this beer would be a lot hoppier but it’s really quite balanced and while rich still doesn’t weigh too hard on your palate. The malt and the hops are balanced really well.

# About the Brewer:  

Craft brewers are know for unorthodox names but this one definitely takes it to the next level. Heretic brewing’s “Confessional” (yes that’s right they call their tap room The Confessional) is located in Fairfield California. 

# Drink this if You Like: 

American Strongs, Hoppy Browns, Strong Ales

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Inciting a riot, Taking or religious types

# Drink While You Are: 

On trial, About to get burned at the steak.

# Pair With: 

Steak, Gumbo, Jambalaya, Red Thai Curry

# Beer Description

Affiliated with the Nectar Ales experience through
shared origins at Humboldt Brewing Company, Hemp Ale is a one-of-a-kind
brew that boasts an incredibly rich profile and unique herb-accented
flavor that is attributable to the incorporation of hemp seeds into the
brewing process. A wonderful brown ale full of complexity Hemp Ale is
great with food or by itself. American hops create a perfect balance to
the darker malts used in this brew. This brown ale is the Gold Medal
winner for first place in its category at both the 1999 and 2000
California State Fair Craft Brewing Competitions

# The Boys’ Take

Rosty and dark with just enough body for a brown
ale Humboldt’s brown ale is right on the money. Notes of chocolate, nut,
and caramel malts a really solid brown ale.

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be
all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft
microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern
California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their
carbon footprint, and who doesn’t love that? In 2005, the little
Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total
Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale
after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex,
malty beers from these nature lovers!

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Brown Ales, Porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a picnic, refilling your bird feeder

# Pair With

Beef stew, Roast Lamb, Shepherd’s Pie.

# Beer Description

Boasting a ruby hue and an exquisite floral aroma, Red Nectar is a robust yet elegant brew with distinctive accents of toasted malt, caramel, spice and residual sweetness. The beer that started it all… Red Nectar was considered a strange bird when it was first released in 1987. After all, where did a robust, handcrafted all-natural amber ale fit into the massive flock of American industrial lagers? Answer: it didn't. So it blazed its own trail, helping set the pace for the craft brew revolution. Enjoy Red Nectar for its dazzling reddish copper hue, original flavors and caramel spice accents

# The Boys' Take

Flavorful, tasty and malty. This one starts sweet with the smell and the taste- maybe a little bit like a snack of fruit, then there's a spice taste. Finally, you may feel some slight fruity hops hit the back of your throat. Amber ales are normally a relatively tame bunch, but this one has some complexity.

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their carbon footprint, and who doesn't love that? In 2005, the little Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex, malty beers from these nature lovers!

# Drink this if You Like

Amber ales, porters, doppelbocks, smooth-drinking beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a picnic, refilling your bird feeder

# Pair With

Chicken, vegetables, hamburgers, sandwiches

# Beer Description

Rare Vos is flemmish for "Sly Fox," and the name of one of Brussels' great cafes. It has a sweetly fruity malt character and yeasty spiciness. A fine dose of yeast permits the beer to mature and mellow in the bottle.

# What you should know

The name is inspired by the cafés (such as Rare Vos) that serve these soft, yeasty amber ales all throughout Belgium. This one of the maltier brews on offer for Ommegang and features Styrian Goulding hops.

# The Boys' Take

Rare Vos will remind you a little of cherries and other dark fruit as you sip it, but not in an overpowering way. Most of the flavors are mellow and soft, with the yeast flavor definitely still shining through. It remains light throughout and finishes dry. Sorta like a gassed water you might be given at a Flemish café.

# About the Brewer

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashion after old-school Belgian traditions. The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY. Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition). Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery. In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast. Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US. In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink if you Like

Dubbels, lambics, Amber ales

# Ideal for People who Like

European cafes and checkered tablecloths, San Pellegrino

# Drink While You Are

Eating moules frites or Belgian waffles, seeking a sophisticated beverage.

# Pair With

Cheese, rich desserts, risotto, mustard greens, chili

Arrogant Bastard Ale
alcohol.untappdString: Arrogant Bastard Ale (Arrogant Bastard Brewing Co.)
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-18099_5ec15_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

This is an aggressive ale. You probably won't like it. It is quite doubtful that you have the taste or sophistication to be able to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth. We would suggest that you stick to safer and more familiar territory–maybe something with a multi-million dollar ad campaign aimed at convincing you it's made in a little brewery, or one that implies that their tasteless fizzy yellow beverage will give you more sex appeal. Perhaps you think multi-million dollar ad campaigns make things taste better. Perhaps you're mouthing your words as you read this.

# What You Should Know

This beer may be feeling itself a little. If you need more details, visit its home page. www.arrogantbastard.com

# The Boy's Take

Don't be scared off by the aggressive title and marketing. What you really get here is healthy (but manageable) dose of flavor. There's a really strong malt flavor here that you'll notice first- a little heavy on the tongue. And then come the hops- BOOM. There's a lot of them, and it's a real bitter, spicy flavor, but one we're sure you'll enjoy… if you're up to it.

# About the Brewer

Stone, located in Escondido, CA, is brash, fun, and serious about beer. Co-founders Greg Koch and Steve Wagner met in 1989 and quickly discovered they both loved brewing. Not so quickly, they decided to open a brewery. Greg was the business man, Steve the brewmaster. They brewed beers that define the West Coast style- adventurous and hop-forward. They released the Arrogant Bastard strong ale (a revolution at the time) and quickly grew a reputation for not being afraid to stand up to the big guys. Along the way, they've become pretty big themselves, now being available almost everywhere. In fact, Stone is one of the top 5000 fastest-growing private companies in the US… and has been for 10 straight years. The icing on the cake? Stone became the first craft brewery to stake its flag in the heard of the beer universe- Germany. Just this year, they announced that they will be opening a brewery in Berlin. Woah.

# Drink this if You Like

Lots of Malts. Lots of Hops

# Ideal for People who Like

Bastards (which is all women if you ask the IT Crowd), not being ashamed to toot your own horn

# Drink While You Are

Feeling smug, needing of a kick in the face

# Pair With

Pork chops, duck tacos, food that can stand up to the Bastard

alcohol.name: Apocalypse IPA
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-_12786_0b762061e2e3f650c0d8ef37182c.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description:  

A Northwest American-Style IPA. The color comes through as a deep gold with orange hues. Fruity and citrusy hop aroma shines, with hints of pine resin. The four hop flavor dominates, re-enforcing the aroma with more citrus, fruity and piney notes. The malt character is clean and smooth with a unique toasted flavor (thanks to the generous helping of Victory malt), all held together by a firm bitterness. Apocalypse has a medium-bodied mouth feel, finishing crisp and dry. All of this results in a very drinkable IPA

# What you should know: 

Along with the basic Centennial and Cascade hops, Horizon hops here are used to bring bitterness, but without harshness- making Apocalypse as drinkable as possible. Amarillo hops, meanwhile, are all citrus- meaning this beer might even trick you into thinking it’s sweet     

# The Boys’ Take: 

The boys at 10 Barrel made this to be both flavorful and approachable.  It’s not crazy- but after a few sips dammit- you appreciate it.  It’s just a really good, really drinkable IPA.  Cheers to THAT.

# About the Brewer: 

Brew beer. Drink Beer. Have fun doing it.  Those are the mottos of 10 Barrel- and although we don’t do as much of the first one as we’d like, we definitely do numbers two and three a lot- and even we can’t keep up with these guys. And we love their spirit, because, after all, brothers Chris and Jeremy Cox didn’t actually know how to brew when they started the brewery.  They just loved beer, and brought on some of the best in the business to create signature recipes.  This enterprising spirit, plus some damn good beer, led 10 Barrel to be one of the most successful Oregon breweries (a crowded field).  So successful, in fact, that AB/In-Bev/Coors/Mega Beer actually bought them in 2014, meaning more 10 Barrel for everyone!

# Drink if you Like: 

IPAs, DIPAs

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Fun, irreverence, the end of the world

# Drink While You Are: 

Battling aliens or the four horsemen, getting crunk

# Pair With:  

Blue cheese, cheddar, curry, fish, chicken, thai

# Beer Description

Back in Black is our newest year-round beer available now in six pack cans and on draft. Brewed like an American IPA but with the addition of rich, dark malts, this beer has all the flavor and hop character you expect with a smooth, mellow finish.

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious, They just have the advantage of pulling it maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs plus a rich, dark taste, stouts, IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

AC/DC, the original Coke, being cool, the "darker side" of things

# Drink While You Are

Trying to stand out, feeling cold but still wanting an IPA

# Pair With

Red meat, BBQ ribs, Burgers, Shepherd's Pie, Wheat Pancakes (why not!)

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Originally brewed in 1975 to commemorate Paul Revere's ride, this brew is a heavily hopped ale (Cascade hops) with a copper color and a hoppy nose.

# What You Should Know

Liberty Ale is single hopped and dry-hopped, two concepts that were revolutionary in 1975 when this beer first appeared. Then the beer is aged in casks with bungs to promote natural carbonation.

# The Boys' Take

Is this a Pale Ale? Is it an IPA? Since this one was invented sooo early, it sorta defies classification as either. It was a true trend-setter with its emphasis on dry-hopping. It's not going to be too bitter, but does have a nice kick to it. Real grapefruity!

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing. Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today. Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries). The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air. To be honest, we're not sure what effect that has. But it most do something. Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat. The original copper brewing equipment is still there. The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales and IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Originality, tradition, the best beer to come out of the 70s

# Drink While You Are

Celebrating being American, or being a blacksmith, or riding horses at midnight

# Pair With

Chicken, nutty cheeses, salad, fish, Italian, BBQ

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Our India Pale Ale exhibits a complex hop aroma, largely due to the generous usage of Cascade and Centennial hops, as well as a subtle malt character from the various malts used to achieve the wonderful balance exhibited in a world-class IPA. San Diego has become world renown for the wonderful and flavorful beers produced here – and India Pale Ales are no exception. Our national award winning interpretation of the style reflects both the history of IPA and the American variation of this distinct beverage. We hope you enjoy it!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Imperial IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Award Winning beers, Wonder Bread

# Drink While You Are

Sitting down, Missioning

# Pair With

Traditional Mexican Fare, Grilled Meats

# Beer Description

If you have fallen for the IPA style like we have, Big Eye will be a welcome addition to your repertoire. You'll revel in Big Eye's bitter, hoppy flavor thanks to the American Columbus and Centennial hops that are used to flavor and dry hop our flagship IPA. We thank our hops every day that the English loved their bitters—or else the IPA style may not have been born to help the beer survive the journey from Cape Hope to India back in the 18th century

# What you should know

This is your traditional American West Coast IPA- lots of Columbus hops flavor and then dry-hopping with Centennial. Centennial hops are one of our favorites- a nice piney smell and citrusy taste.

# The Boys' Take

Not flashy, so solid. A really nice body of malts holds up the floral tastes that we are desperately seeking. Due to the Centennial dry-hopping, we get a lot of grassy and flowery flavor here.

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers. Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene. Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world. As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out. Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born. Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Double IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Coronado, Grapefruit, the smell of freshly-cut grass

# Drink While You Are

Eating sushi, resting after kiteboarding

# Food Pairings

Sweet Hawaiian fish, Curry, Cured meat

# Beer Description

Named after Coronado Island, our original India Pale Ale is a liquid expression of hometown pride. Cascade, Chinook, and Columbus hops combine to provide an explosive burst of piney bitterness and lucioius notes of apricot, grapefruit, and mango that are sure to envoke imagery of swinging palms and sun-kissed shores.

# What You Should Know

The Islander IPA swings for a tropical home run. All three of the C's (the hop varieties used here) come with a fruity, juicy taste.

# The Boy's Take

This one is sweeter than most IPAs, with a light body that does surprisingly well to not taste like alcohol at 7%. A the finish, it really does carry a little bit like a nice Tequila Sunrise, with some citrusy sweetness.

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America's greatest beach (Coronado) and their first keg delivery was straight to the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000 barrels a year, and we can't wait for an ever-greater selection to be available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit, the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Drink this if You Like

West Coast IPAs, Tropical Drinks

# Ideal for People who Like

Mojitos, Pina Coladas, Sunbathing

# Drink While You Are

Finding your beach, doing some California Dreaming

# Food Pairings

Curried food, Thai food, peppery cheese, sharp cheddar

alcohol.name: Union Jack IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description:  

An instant classic, Union Jack is the recipient of numerous awards including back to back wins at the Great American Beer Festival. Union Jack is abound with hop aroma and character. In fact this well balanced, west coast IPA is dry hopped 3 separate times, each lot giving it more and more of the grapefruit citrus hop aroma and flavor it is known for. Overall it utilizes over 4 pounds of pacific northwest hops per barrel.

# The Boys’ Take: 

This is a Californian IPA. Bright auburn color, some sweet malts and then the rich, tangy flavors of pine and citrus- tasty!

# About the Brewer:  

Firestone Walker is located in Paso Robles, California a location more known for its wine production than its brewing. Started in 1996 by brother-in-laws Adam Firestone (yes he’s from the Firestone tire family) and David Walker, Firestone Walker is one of the biggest breweries in California. Firestone walkerowns another brewery, Humboldt Brewing, and is partially owned by Duvel Brewing from Belgium.

# Drink if you Like: 

IPAs, fruit-forward beers

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Breezes, palm trees, the crash of the waves on the shore

# Drink While You Are: 

Going to your happy place

# Beer Description

Get ready to bask in the glory of the frothy head's floral bouquet. Relish the citrus accents from the abundance of dry hopping. This one's sweet, yet balanced. Malty undertones shake hands with the hop character for a finish that never turns too bitter.

# What you should know

Normally, hops are added to the boiling wort (the hot soup of malt and hops that you then but in the fermenter). When this happens, the hops provide the bitterness that you're used to. But dry-hopping, that's different. This doesn't add any bitterness- but it does bring tons of floral/grassy flavor and aroma. So if you're not a hop-fan don't let "dry-hopped" scare you away!

# The Boys' Take

This might be the easiest-drinking IPA out there. Even if you're a diehard Simcoe (hops) guy or girl, you can appreciate this beer. But- brace yourself- this will surprise you as an IPA. There's no bitter punch in the face here- its malty, buttery and biscuity from the beginning, and then only at the end do you get the refreshing hit of bitterness from the hops

# About the Brewer

Founder's Brewery is the pride and joy of Grand Rapids, MI. Mike Stevens and Dave Engbers started the brewer, and very quickly they realized they were running out of money- so they decided to stop playing it safe. Since then, Founder's has been a different brewery. This isn't the place that has crazy names or themes. The names are simple, but the beer can be complex. Check out the Breakfast Stout in the winter and the Harvest Ale in fall.

# Drink this if You Like

Centennial hops, smooth-drinking hops, Session IPAs, blonde ales

# Ideal for People who Like

The number 100, the smell of freshly-cut hay

# Drink While You Are

Trying something new, working on the farm

# Pair with

Spicy food, BBQ, Thai, Indian

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Malt and hops are beautifully married in this full-bodied, copper-red Pale Ale. Red Seal Ale is generously hopped in the traditional manner for a long, spicy finish.

# What you should know

Pale ales grew up as a term for the strongest ales carried in English pubs. More than other English beers, lighter malts in the pale ale allowed hops to do most of the talking. The copper malts in Red Seal Ale give it a dry, toasted feel, extenuating the punch that the bitter hops bring.

# The Boy's Take

The darker malts in this beer make us lean more towards a hoppy amber ale, but who are we to argue with North Coast? The malts here are slightly sweet, and the hops aren't overwhelming but instead nicely balanced and herby, which balances quite well with the more robust body. We like it.

# About the Brewer

North Coast brewing is a veteran in the craft beer scene. In 2015, they don't care about being cool, trendy or buzz-worthy. Just a group of craftsmen concentrating on making excellent beer. We might suggest a slight update to the website, but we don't suppose these guys care. Mark Ruedrich started North Coast in 1988 on the picturesque Mendocino coast (north of San Francisco), just down Hwy 1 from Mendocino brewing. Mark doesn't seem to be about flashy new releases, fancy labels and hot styles. Instead, North Coast has a broad range, one that hasn't changed much in years (although more recently NCB has resurrected the old ACME brewing label from 1800's San Francisco). You may know the Old Rasputin Imperial Stout. Drink that, but we also recommend Old Stock Ale and the Old No. 38 Stout.

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Pacific sea mammals, whiskers, Sea World

# Drink While You Are

Sitting on a rocky beach, sun bathing, avoiding Killer Whales

# Pair With

Quesadillas, salsa, steak and other red meat, spinach salad, andouille

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Abita Purple Haze is a crisp, American style wheat beer with fresh raspberries added during secondary fermentation. Subtle coloration, fruity aroma and tartly sweet taste.

# What you Need to Know

This beer is a lager, meaning is fermented with lager yeast and kept cold (45-50 degrees) during fermentation. This keeps the flavors crisp and clear (instead of influences by other flavors in the air). The raspberries are added after the beer is bottled.

# About the Brewer

Abita was founded in 1986, and is in many ways the quintessential Southern beer. Brewed in Abita Springs, LA (40 minutes north of New Orleans), Abita makes a wide range of brews, some of which are perfect for pairing with seersucker and sticky nights- and that's something we need here in the South. Another added benefit is the pure, deep water from Abita Springs- this is the last little bit that kicks Abita beer "up a notch!" Most Abita beers are light drinking and perfect for summer nights, and are made with all-natural, high-quality ingredients.

# Drink this if You Like

Smooth lagers, sweet/tangy beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Louisiana, raspberries, Jimmy Hendricks, Seer sucker

# Drinking While you Are

Boogying, or at a hoedown

# Pair with

Salad, light dessert, chocolate, Brie, mascarpone, citrus
