alcohol.name: Purple Haze

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Anchor Steam® Beer owes its deep amber color, thick, creamy head, and rich, distinctive flavor to a historic brewing process like none other. It is a process that combines deep respect for craft brewing tradition with many decades of evolution to arrive at a unique approach: a blend of pale and caramel malts, fermentation with lager yeast at warmer ale temperatures in shallow open-air fermenters, and gentle carbonation in our cellars through an all-natural process called kräusening.

# What You Should Know

The open-air fermentation process leads to a flavor complexity and a taste different really from any other beer.

# The Boys' Take

Much like steam, this one is thin and light- but it has a stiff bite. You'll definitely taste both barley and hops here.

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing. Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today. Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries). The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air. To be honest, we're not sure what effect that has. But it most do something. Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat. The original copper brewing equipment is still there. The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, crisp Lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

San Francisco, fog, openness and transparency

# Drink While You Are

Overlooking the Golden Gate bridge, readying for the gold rush

# Pair With

Seafood, seasoned poultry

Longfin Lager
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Our Longfin Lager has become one of the go-to beers with the team at the brewery. A solidly balanced Helles inspired Lager with a clean, slightly hoppy finish that could easily fit in at any German beer garden. We think it's perfect for enjoying on the beach, the boat or anywhere else you can put an ice chest full of bee

# What you should know

Lager can seem like a derogatory term due to its reminder of American mass-produced beers, but actually, lagering is simply one of the oldest types of beer technology. Lager yeasts ferment at a lower temperature than ale yeasts and brew more purely. This can mean more consistency and smoother, if less complex taste. A Helles Lager, such as this one, is characteristically German- it's more malt-forward than it's cousin the Pilsener

# The Boys' Take

This is style that isn't going to bring any wild flavors to the table, but this is a very well-crafted example. The malt flavor is nice and well-balanced. The hop flavors are going to be kinda traditional German flavors and mostly subdued.

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers. Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene. Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world. As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out. Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born. Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea

# Drink this if You Like

Pilseners, lagers, blonde ales, Kolschs

# Ideal for People who Like

Fishing, the Beach (but without Corona), San Diego

# Drink While You Are

Fishing, at the beach, telling a fish tale

# Food Pairings

White Fish, Citrus, Cantalope

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Our spiced California style Wit is both refreshing
and complex. Brewed with wheat, coriander, California orange peel and
local orange blossom honey. From the first sip to the last you’ll find
subtle flavors of bread, spice, citrus and a thirst quenching orange
honey finish.

# The Boys’ Take

This is an aggressive take on a witbier, with lots
of orange peel and coriander flavor and a malty finish.

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island
roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America’s
greatest beach (Coronado) and their first keg delivery was straight to
the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick
Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look
for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000
barrels a year, and we can’t wait for an ever-greater selection to be
available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit,
the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Drink if you Like

Witbiers, Belgian ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Going over the top, getting aggressive

# Drink While You Are

Charging it up, dishing out some orange slices

# Pair With

Shellfishes, mussels, omlets

# Beer Description: 

Crafted in the city that gives us 329 days of sun, 329 Lager is the perfect companion for making the most of sunny California days. Our go anywhere, do anything lager is full-flavored and easy-drinking with a clean, crisp finish.

# The Boys’ Take: 

A great smooth American lager that is a great way to step into craft beer and away from some of those so called “American Lagers”…  

# About the Brewer:  

Golden Road Brewing was founded in 2011 by Meg Gill and Tony Yanow in Los Angeles, California. They focus on brewing beer that is sustainable and their community together. Golden Road Brewing was recently acquired by AB InBev but is still brewing their beer with excellence. Enjoy!

# Drink this if You Like: 

Lagers, Pale Ales, Blondes

The Golden State, Birkenstocks, Surfing

Grilling burgers on an open fire in Yosemite

Burgers, Kebabs, anything off the grill.

alcohol.name: Four Star Pils
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description 

This golden-hued pilsner has a light, fresh body and clean finish. Bright, refreshing carbonation mingles with German and American hops to give this pilsner a unique Goose Island spin.

# The Boy’s Take

The crafty cure to the common Pils. This seasonal Pils brewed by the folks at Goose Island once again proves that just because they got picked up by the big guys doesn’t mean they’re not still making great craft beer!

# About the Brewer

Goose Island is Chicago’s microbrewery, launched in 1988 by founder John Hall, just returned from a European tour.  More than just making good craft beer, Hall advocated for it, helping bring consciousness of this new revolution to one of the US’s largest cities.  This meant growth, and by 1995, it was time for another brewery.  Along the way, Hall had built smaller pilot beer labs and 143,000 sqft of barrel space for barrel-aging beers.  This was revolutionary, and it got Goose Island its name, especially for the Bourbon Country Barrel-Aged Stout (released once a year on Black Friday and notorious for creating long lines far from the shopping malls).  But eventually there was a cap to the growth, and Annheiser-Busch came calling.  Yes, Goose Island has been owned by A-B for several years and that has meant… a lot more Goose Island.  Most would agree, the quality of the beer is still top-notch, you just can get Goose Island in a lot more places, thanks to A-B.  And there’s nothing wrong with that.

# Drink this if You Like

Goldens, Pale Ales, Pale Lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

Geese, The Windy City, an original 

# Drink While You Are

At home in your library, looking out over Lake Michigan, catching a Cubs game 

# Pair With

Burgers, Chicago Dogs, Chicago Style Pizza

alcohol.name: Pilsener
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

While our Cascade Pils is inspired by classic European pilsners, this beer is really a celebration of the fresh, local Cascade hops grown by family farmers right here in our beloved Pacific Northwest. It has intense aromas of citrus and pine, supported by a medium body and dry malty palate. As you savor that unmistakable aroma and long, clean hop finish, tip your hat (and your glass) to the generations of hop farmers who help us live the locavore dream every day. We originally brewed Cascade Pilsner as a special release to celebrate our 26th Anniversary and our Northwest hop growers. It quickly became our fastest growing Full Sail draft beer and our bestselling 22oz. bottle. With that warm consumer response we decided it deserved its own year round six-pack.

# What you should know

Hop growing areas are concentrated at latitudes between 35 and 55 degrees (North or South) of the equator, as the long days during the growing season are essential to strong yields. 97% of hops production in North America comes from Washington, Oregon and Idaho.

# The Boy's Take

More hop-forward than many other pilseners, this light-bodied lager uses floral hops to carry the flavor forward rather than the bitter malts found in more traditional styles. Think of it like a light pale ale.

# About the Brewer

Full Sail is the 9th largest craft brewery in the United States by sales volume. They were founded in 1987 and are located in Hood River, Oregon. By accounts, Full Sail is decidedly low-key- their website and labels are kinda retro and you aren't likely to hear them make waves in the craft beer industry. They don't make a million varieties of beer. They just focus on making good beers, although we wouldn't recommend them for most of the hopheads. Try out their Barleywine, Old Boardhead or the Wassail (an English Strong Ale brewed in the winter)

# Drink this if You Like

PIlseners, Session IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Rain, family farms, counter-culture

# Drink While You Are

Getting a new tattoo, checking out vintage apparel

# Pair With

German, pork, poultry

# Beer Description:  

A Crisp Citrus Beer with a hint of Tangerine.

# What you Need to Know:

This beer is a lager, meaning is fermented with lager yeast and kept cold (45-50 degrees) during fermentation.  This keeps the flavors crisp and clear (instead of influences by other flavors in the air).  Tangerine and citrus aromas come through strongly.

# About the Brewer:  

The Lost Coast Brewery and Café began with a dream.  In 1986 Barbara Groom, a pharmacist wondered what it would require to start a brewpub.  After years honing her skills home brewing, planning and studying scores of pubs throughout England & Wales Barbara was ready to transform the dream into a reality.
Since its humble beginning in 1990, the brewery has outgrown not just its original facility in the Pythian Castle, but has also outgrown the site it moved to in 1993 just down the street. After a long successful 25 years and breaking two production records in 2005 with 24,000 barrels, and 2009 with over 50,000 barrels, the brewery is now located at the south end of Eureka, California in a brand new state of the art facility. Barbara Groom designed it to not only make exceptional brews in, but to be open for the public to enjoy as well, opening Summer 2015. Currently the new facility is brewing at a 90,000-barrel capacity and is still working to brew to greater heights!

# Drink this if You Like: 

Smooth lagers, sweet/tangy beer

# Ideal for People who Like: 

Boating without a GPS, Fruit Ninja

# Drinking While you Are: 

Looking for Land, Lounging under Palm Fronds

# Pair with: 

Fruit Salad, Hawaiian Pizza, Grilled Snapper with Mango Chutney

alcohol.name: Tangerine Wheat

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

A Beer Cloaked in Secrecy, An ale whose mysterious and unusual palate will swirl across your tongue and ask more questions than it answers. A beer brewed clandestinely and given a name whose meaning is never revealed. Why #9? Why, indeed. A sort of dry, crisp, fruity, refreshing, not-quite pale ale. #9 is really impossible to describe because there's never been anything else quite like it. Fermented with our 150 year old strain of top-fermenting English yeast.

# What You Should Know

\#9 starts with the base of a traditional Pale Ale- pale and crystal malts that are light and somewhat sweet. Cascade and Centennial hops, two varieties that are used very commonly in craft beer, so it's a familiar base. The secret differentiator is the addition of apricot flavorings (it's top secret what gives the actual flavor) to give the beer a sweet and fruity finish.

# The Boy's Take

This one is interesting- a sorta hybrid with a solid pale ale start and little bit of an interesting fruit twist at the end. It's eminently drinkable and a really solid choice.

# About the Brewer

Magic Hat was founded in 1994 in Burlington, VT and quickly proved to be a successful pioneer in the craft beer space. The interesting thing about Magic Hat is that they provide beer that is palatable to a mainstream audience or new craft beer drinkers, but at the same time are known for quirkiness and creativity in their marketing in culture. A trip to the artifactory is a bit of a crazy ride, with haunted-house décor, real pieces of art and free beer samplers. In 2008, it was time to grow and Magic Hat acquired Pyramid brewing from Washington state, giving them a coast to coast reach. Finally, North American Breweries (owned by a private equity group that also owns Genesee and Dundee brewing), came in to add Magic Hat to its empire in 2010- which means more Magic Hat beer everywhere!

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, Brown Ales, Fruit Beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Apricots, secret formulas, Wikileaks

# Drink While You Are

Touring Mr. Magoo's Magic Emporium, performing a magic trick

# Pair With

Indian, Thai, Chinese, Southwestern

# Beer Description

Ommegang Witte, a traditional Belgian-style wheat ale with whispers of sweet orange and a touch of tart lemon. Soft and seductive.

# What You Should Know

A very highly rated Witbeir. If you like Blue Moon, you’ll love this. Brewed in the Belgian-style, so be sure to look for the Orange peel and coriander flavors. Serve in a tumbler or a weizen.

# About the Brewer

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashion after old-school Belgian traditions.  The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY.  Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition).  Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery.   In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast.  Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US.  In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink this if You Like

Blue Moon, Witbeirs, Wheat Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Soft and seductive beers, Traditional recipes 

# Drink While You Are

Touring the baseball hall of fame, Pruning citrus trees

# Pair With

Steamed Mussels, Chicken Piccata, Veal Parmesan

Blonde
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

While this beer is light in color, it's not lacking in flavor. This easy drinking beer has fruity and floral notes with a clean finish. A healthy dose of wheat malt adds to the complexity you would expect from a blonde.

# What You Need to Know

The Blonde ale is actually a creation of American craft brewers to explain a less-extensively hopped, but still pale, ale made traditionally in England. Used to light lagers, American drinkers quickly took to this maltier style- and then Blonde Ales found their way back to England as a style all their own!

# The Boys' Take

Tip a few of these back- they're easy to drink! The taste is mostly malt, with some floral hop flavor, but nothing too crazy

# About the Brewer

Fortnight is definitely the total hybrid of English sensibilities and, well, America. The brewery is drab and unassuming, but walk in, and there is tons of room- high ceilings and space to breathe (something you don't see in many pubs). But the magnificent wooden bar is there, with a couple of casks perched for on-the-spot infusions and aging. Yes, Fortnight is very much a representation of, well, England, and all its beers fill that mold. Now, English beers are not like American ones- they are typically lower in both alcohol and complexity, but no less care is used in making them. The good thing is that you can have five while watching soccer and get away with it. The team, a collection of beer-lovers drawn to the Raleigh-Durham area by various corporate jobs, founded the brewery only recently- but bring a mixture of organization and ambition that has Fortnight on the right track, we just know it.

# Drink this if You Like

English beer, Blonde Ales, Kolsch, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Blondes over Brunettes, Having more fun

# Drink While You Are

Enduring a rainy day, in a red phone booth, eating kidney pie
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-576048_7564d_sm.jpeg

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Samuel Adams Boston Lager® is the best example of the fundamental characteristics of a great beer, offering a full, rich flavor that is both balanced and complex. It is brewed using a decoction mash, a time consuming, traditional four vessel brewing process discarded by many contemporary brewers. This process brings forth a rich sweetness from the malt that makes it well worth the effort. Samuel Adams Boston Lager® also uses only the finest of ingredients including two row barley, as well as German Noble aroma hops. The exclusive use of two row barley not only imparts a full, smooth body but also gives the beer a wide spectrum of malt flavor ranging from slightly sweet to caramel to slightly roasted. The Noble hops varieties, Hallertau Mittelfruh and Tettnang Tettnanger, add a wide range of floral, piney and citrus notes, which are present from the aroma, through the flavor, to the lingering smooth finish. We take great pride in the Noble hops used in our beers. They are hand selected by Jim Koch and our other brewers from the world's oldest hops growing area. Among the world's most expensive, they cost twenty times as much as other hops.

# What you should know

This was the beer that some say started it all. It was Boston Beer (Sam Adams) very first beer, and one of the first that lead the revolution of using the highest quality ingredients and brewed to a premium quality.

# The Boys' Take

It's been such a long time, it's easy to overlook the old Boston Lager, but there's something to be said for the straight-forward, traditional taste of the beer that "started it all"

# About the Brewer

Boston Beer (aka Sam Adams) is the 300-pound gorilla in any craft beer conversation. In fact, the official definition of "craft beer" was changed in 2010 to make sure Sam Adams was considered craft beer, when they first brewed more than 2 million barrels. Their 2013 revenues were more than 3 times the second-biggest brewer. So yeah, we're talking a different ball game. This makes Sam Adams a divisive topic in the craft beer world. If you listen to Boston Beer, they are still a great innovator and help open a bigger market for craft beer with their big budget and TV ad campaigns. If you ask the hopheads, they are an unimaginative, lumbering giant that deserves to be treated like one of the big boys. We still think they make good beer, and if we know you'll like it, we'll bring you some

# Drink if you Like

Lagers, old school beers, easy-drinking beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Oldies but goodies, the 80s, American patriots

# Drink While You Are

Planning a tea party perhaps?

# Pair With

BBQ, ribs, calamari

# Beer Description

As summer heats up, this light-bodied session ale with fresh orange aroma is crisp, easy drinking and endlessly refreshing. Brewed with hops from Elk Mountain Farms, Goose Summer Ale will be a staple at backyard BBQs and outdoor adventures for the whole summer.

# The Boy's Take

One of our favorite summer time beers, Goose's Summer Ale hits some really nice balanced notes of slightly sweet malts, with restrained but slightly sour citus hops

# About the Brewer

Goose Island is Chicago's microbrewery, launched in 1988 by founder John Hall, just returned from a European tour. More than just making good craft beer, Hall advocated for it, helping bring consciousness of this new revolution to one of the US's largest cities. This meant growth, and by 1995, it was time for another brewery. Along the way, Hall had built smaller pilot beer labs and 143,000 sqft of barrel space for barrel-aging beers. This was revolutionary, and it got Goose Island its name, especially for the Bourbon Country Barrel-Aged Stout (released once a year on Black Friday and notorious for creating long lines far from the shopping malls). But eventually there was a cap to the growth, and Annheiser-Busch came calling. Yes, Goose Island has been owned by A-B for several years and that has meant… a lot more Goose Island. Most would agree, the quality of the beer is still top-notch, you just can get Goose Island in a lot more places, thanks to A-B. And there's nothing wrong with that.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, Session IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Geese, The Windy City, Being Unfiltered

# Drink While You Are

At home in your library, looking out over Lake Michigan, catching a Cubs game

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Kellerweis is one of the only American Hefeweizens made using the traditional Bavarian style of open fermentation. This difficult and labor-intensive technique adds uncommon depth and flavor complexity. Our hazy-golden hefeweizen is deeply flavorful, refreshing and perfect for a sunny day. To serve, pour two-thirds into a glass, swirl and pour the rest.

# What You Should Know

Open fermentation leads to the development of additional "esters", or acids that are created and lead to fruity, soft flavors.  The additional warmth and space in open fermentation is perfect for development of these flavors.

# The Boys’ Take

One of the best wheat beers in the US, the Kellerweis is simply a pleasure to drink- sweet first, but with a well-developed sense of flavor- light cloves and just a little bit of banana

# About the Brewer

The third-largest craft brewer in the US, Sierra Nevada has proven that it belongs at the very top of the rankings since 1980.  From the beginning, Sierra Nevada beer has been a celebration of spicy American hops, and they’ve never backed down from that.  And they’ve earned their upper-tier position by forging a path that in 1980 barely existed.  Hops were hard to find.  Brewery equipment didn’t come on a micro scale.  Then they came up with the Pale Ale, which was instrumental in bringing the West Coast style to the mainstream.  Finally in 1987, Sierra Nevada moved into downtown Chico and setup shop.  Now they are a N. California fixture and also have a brewery in the works in Asheville, NC.  To this day, Sierra Nevada is still synonymous with hoppy, fresh beer, and we hope that never changes

# Drink this if You Like

Hefeweizens, American Wheat ales, Tripels

# Ideal for People who Like

Germany, words that begin with K, yeast

# Drink While You Are

Enjoing a warm day, going on a hike

# Pair With

Fruit Salad, Grilled Salmon, Bratwurst, Brie, Camembert

# Beer Description

Gather your friends, pack the gear, and head out to wherever the day may take you. A midday go-to, Nooner is our take on the classic German-style pilsner—one of the original session beers. Nooner is easy drinking yet packed with the big flavor of spicy and floral whole-cone hops. Its brilliant golden color begs you to take a sip and sink your taste buds into an extremely welcoming beer, full of flavor and balanced by a crisp, dry finish.

# The Boy's Take

This here is a quality pilsener. Not spicy or bitey, it's quality-made, with just a little bit of malt to hold everything together. Generally, the taste is very dry

# About the Brewer

# Beer Description: 

There is no beautifier of complexion, or form, or behavior, like the wish to scatter joy and not pain around us. Crisp Lager has nothing to hide behind - no makeup to cover up any flaws. Raw ingredients and their essence, full and unabated...uninhibited...CRISP

# What You Need to Know: 

Pilseners originated in the Czech Republic, believe it or not, but once the style was adopted to Germany, the German brewers slightly adopted the style to have a bit more body and show a bit less spicy hops. Sixpoints doesn’t define which style they’re aiming for, but we tend to think of this more like a Czech pils.

# The Boys’ Take: 

Super dry and refreshing, with a pleasant burst of hopiness at the end.  Balanced, but with a suprising amount of hops in there.

# About the Brewer:  

Sixpoint Brewing is legit, and our Chief Design Officer, Sam loves their website. Plus, they have those Red Bull-style, thinner cans, which is different. Andrew Brownstein and Shane Welch hail from Brooklyn, although much of the beer is brewed upstate. They came on the scene in 2004 and the skinny cans came in 2011.  What’s in the logo, you ask? It’s a mixture of a hexagram and a nautical star.

# Drink this if You Like: 

Lagers, German styles, Pilsners

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Wafers, freshly cleaned sheets

# Drink While You Are: 

Travelling the German-Czech border

# Pair With: 

Potato wedges, fried chicken, caprese salad

Pilsener
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

While our Cascade Pils is inspired by classic European pilsners, this beer is really a celebration of the fresh, local Cascade hops grown by family farmers right here in our beloved Pacific Northwest. It has intense aromas of citrus and pine, supported by a medium body and dry malty palate. As you savor that unmistakable aroma and long, clean hop finish, tip your hat (and your glass) to the generations of hop farmers who help us live the locavore dream every day. We originally brewed Cascade Pilsner as a special release to celebrate our 26th Anniversary and our Northwest hop growers. It quickly became our fastest growing Full Sail draft beer and our bestselling 22oz. bottle. With that warm consumer response we decided it deserved its own year round six-pack.

# What you should know

Hop growing areas are concentrated at latitudes between 35 and 55 degrees (North or South) of the equator, as the long days during the growing season are essential to strong yields. 97% of hops production in North America comes from Washington, Oregon and Idaho.

# The Boy's Take

More hop-forward than many other pilseners, this light-bodied lager uses floral hops to carry the flavor forward rather than the bitter malts found in more traditional styles. Think of it like a light pale ale.

# About the Brewer

Full Sail is the 9th largest craft brewery in the United States by sales volume. They were founded in 1987 and are located in Hood River, Oregon. By accounts, Full Sail is decidedly low-key- their website and labels are kinda retro and you aren't likely to hear them make waves in the craft beer industry. They don't make a million varieties of beer. They just focus on making good beers, although we wouldn't recommend them for most of the hopheads. Try out their Barleywine, Old Boardhead or the Wassail (an English Strong Ale brewed in the winter)

# Drink this if You Like

PIlseners, Session IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Rain, family farms, counter-culture

# Drink While You Are

Getting a new tattoo, checking out vintage apparel

# Pair With

German, pork, poultry

# Drink this if You Like

Wheats, kolschs

# Beer Description

Nothing refreshes you more than this naturally cloudy wheat beer with its wonderful yeasty fragrance and taste. Goes well with dishes that do not have too intensive a flavour, especially that Bavarian speciality 'Weisswurst' or white sausage.

# What You Should Know

Although they are normally associated with Belgium, there are monasteries in Germany too!  Weihenstephaner is actually one of the world’s oldest breweries, but instead of Beligan strong ales and abbey ales, you can find here pale lagers and wheat ales.  There is a filtered version of this beer available as well call, considered a Kirstalweizen

# The Boy's Take

Now this is a hefeweizen done correctly.  The wheat grain adds some heft and flavor, but it’s not syrupy sweet or strangely acidic.  Nope, just weighty enough to make the beer satisfying, but soft enough to make it really drinkable.

# About the Brewer

Weihenstephan actually has a claim (no really) to be the oldest brewery in the world- they have manuscripts dating to the 700s (!) talking about hop gardening occurring on the grounds of the monastery.  The actual business of what we would call beer probably started a little bit later, but regardless, these guys know what they are doing, and have been at it for quite a while.  Eventually, the monastery was secularized, and actually converted into a brewing school along with a production brewery!  The wheat beers are some of the world, so if you like those types, we suggest not missing a chance to check them out.

# Ideal for People who Like

German engineering, the Middle Ages, Friar Tuck

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying some wurst, hiking in the alps

# Pair With

Weisswurst, poultry, cheese

# Beer Description

Otra Vez means “another time,” and for Sierra Nevada that time is early California when beers were made from local ingredients. The brewery trialed various native produce searching for great flavors. Prickly pear cactus flourishes in the state’s arid deserts, and grapefruit fills the Central Valley’s flats. Together their fruity-tangy blend makes Otra Vez, whose tartness is true to the gose style, pop with character.

# What you should know

Gose are sour beers that originated in Goslar, Germany- the style started in the 16th Century, but almost went extinct during WWII!  The style is brewed using salt and coriander and often has a lemony flavor.  Super refreshing.  The addition of the blood orange in this one not only gives Anderson Valley’s Gose more citrus, but also a tangy Orange flavor. 

# The Boy’s Take

Not as tart or salty as your typical gose but light and effervescent with a touch of Prickly pear sweet citrus. Excited about having this available poolside this summer!

# About the Brewer

The third-largest craft brewer in the US, Sierra Nevada has proven that it belongs at the very top of the rankings since 1980.  From the beginning, Sierra Nevada beer has been a celebration of spicy American hops, and they’ve never backed down from that.  And they’ve earned their upper-tier position by forging a path that in 1980 barely existed.  Hops were hard to find.  Brewery equipment didn’t come on a micro scale.  Then they came up with the Pale Ale, which was instrumental in bringing the West Coast style to the mainstream.  Finally in 1987, Sierra Nevada moved into downtown Chico and setup shop.  Now they are a N. California fixture and also have a brewery in the works in Asheville, NC.  To this day, Sierra Nevada is still synonymous with hoppy, fresh beer, and we hope that never changes.

# Drink this if You Like

Goses, Lactobacillus-based beers, Wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Prickly Pear, San Pelegrino, friendly bacteria

# Drink While You Are

Looking for crisp, cool refreshment, enjoying a late Spring brunch

# Pair With

Smoked Salmon, Oysters, Pad Thai, Bitter Greens

alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-samuelSmithsNutBrown.jpg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Brewed at Samuel Smith's small, traditional British brewery with well water (the original well sunk in 1758 is still in use), best barley malt, roasted barley, yeast and aromatic hops. Nut Brown Ale is relatively dry with a rich amber-brown color and nutty flavor derived exclusively from small amounts of dark malt. Brown ales are a specialty of northern England. Fermented in 'stone Yorkshire squares'.

# What you should know

The specific well water in Yorkshire, England helps form the base of this traditional brew. Samuel Smith's "Taddy" brewery is also one of the few that uses the Yorkshire Square method of brewing, which actually separates the wort (the boiled malt) from yeasty foam at the top. Periodically, some of the wort is pumped up into the yeast to feed it. Finally, the wort is drained, leaving the yeast behind, and a fairly bitter wort. Fortunately, there is enough residual yeast to stay back and continue to soften the taste. It's a laborious method, but it seems to work for Samuel Smith's

# The Boys' Take

We love our English traditional style beers and Sam Smith's Nut Brown is a perfect example of the style. malty, smooth, toasty flavors, and a medium plus body is perfect for a fall evening!

# About the Brewer

The original brewery that Samuel Smith started from started in 1758, although it wasn't until a couple of generations has passed when the true brewery started operations in 1847. Shortly after, old Samuel developed his yeast strain, and the brewery still uses it today- one of the longest continuous yeast strains there are. Plus, they still deliver their beer using horses (well, around Yorkshire, at least). There's also a line of over 300 pubs run by Samuel Smith's throughout England. So different, indeed.

# Drink if you Like

English-style, understated dark beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Tradition, horses, buggies, Yorkshire pudding

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a pint at the pub

# Pair With

Meat and potatoes, chocolate

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Allagash Black, our new Belgian style stout, is brewed with German 2 row barley, Torrified wheat and oats, balanced by a large addition of Belgian dark candi to give the Black a full and silky mouthfeel. Roasted malts give this stout its classic chocolate, toast and malty taste, and contribute to chocolate notes and a hint of roasted coffee in the aroma. The Black is fermented with a Belgian yeast strain and refermented in the bottle with the methode champenoise to make this beer truly unique

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

alcohol.name: Dubbel
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Allagash Dubbel Reserve boasts a dark malty taste. The finish is dry with subtle hints of chocolate and nuts. With time, Allagash Dubbel Reserve will mature in the bottle and acquire distinctive port and sherry characteristics.

# What You Should Know

Just like all other Allagash beers, this Dubbel will age well! If you have the patience to delay enjoyment, let this one sit for a month or two! Now, the term Dubbel is really much more of a marketing term. The predecessor style is beer made by Trappist monks in Belgium in the mid-1800s. As the turn of the century came and life got harder (apparently), a new recipe was brewed with a stronger alcohol content (thus Dubbel, "Double). Today, Dubbel is one the most-enjoyed Belgian styles and is reminiscent of a more yeasty brown ale with strong alcohol content

# The Boys' Take

For a beer style often characterized by being dry, this one can surprise sometimes with a nice creamy, rich mouthfeel. You won't miss out on the traditional Belgian fuzzy softness, however- you definitely taste the toast one on this. We would recommend the bottle-aging, but we've never had a bottle last that long!

# About the Brewer

You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian beer, Brown ales, lighter stouts

# Drink While You Are

Debating whether to give it all up and retire to a monastery

# Beer Description

Allagash Saison is our interpretation of a classic Belgian farmhouse style. It is a golden hued beer, brewed with a 2-Row blend, malted rye, oats and dark Belgian candi sugar. It was hopped with Tettnang, Bravo and Cascade hops. Fermented with a traditional saison yeast strain, this beer exhibits notes of spice and tropical fruit in the aroma. Citrus and a peppery spice dominate the flavor and make way for a pleasant malts

# What You Should Know

What is a Saison? Well, moyens de Saison en français\* (what Saison means in French) is "season", and Saisons were originally brewed in Belgium on farms for summer drinking. The beer would be brewed in the fall or winter to employ unoccupied farm workers and provide beer for seasonal laborers in the summer. Traditionally, these SaIsons would have strong yeast flavors but a crisp, light color. Originally, the Saisons would have had lower ABVs, in the 1900s the alcohol content started to creep up to 5%-7%. Today, there is great variety in what constitutes a Saison, but almost are extremely dry but still malty. Oh, and they are cool. Really cool. So there's that.

\*Note: this translation was definitely taken from Google Translate. Our apologies if makes no sense whatsoever.

# The Boys' Take

Man, Allagash sure does make good beer. This one is easy on the eyes (being a nice clear yellow) and in the mouth. It's gonna be dry, but very crisp and refreshing. Saisons can seem strange or confusing to the uninitiated, but don't be scared. They all (and especially this one) have a lot to offer!

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian beer, Pale ales, Wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Farmhouses, Belgium, a beer earned with manual labor

# Drink While You Are

On the farm, cooling off after a long day

# Pair With

Asian, Farmhouse Food, Red Meat, French Cuisine

# Beer Description

This golden hued ale is marked by passion fruit and herbal notes in the aroma, with subtle suggestions of banana and honey surfacing from its deep and complex palate. The Tripel's finish is remarkably long and soothing.

# The Boys' Take

Man, Allagash sure does make good beer. This tripel has been held to the same high standards that Allagash has been known for since they first started brewing. If you like rich Belgian style beers with rich complexity and lighter body this is your brew!

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, Saisons.

# Ideal for People who Like

Things that come in 3's, Aperitifs

# Drink While You Are

Winding it down for the night, On your trip to Brussels

# Pair With

Limberger, Rochford, Brie, Camembert, Desserts with honey.

# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float

Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-10891_26699_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Most breweries have at least one piece of equipment that's just a bit persnickity. Here at Boulevard it's fermenter number seven, the black sheep of our cellar family. Ironically, when our brewers were developing variations on a traditional Belgian-style farmhouse ale, the perfect combination of elements came together in that very vessel. You could call it fate, but they called it Tank 7, and so it is. Beginning with a flavorful surge of fruity aromatics and hoppy, grapefruit notes (Amarillo hops), this complex, straw-colored ale finishes long, dry and spicy.

# The Boy's Take

A very traditional Belgian Saison with just a little extra floral hops, and grapefruit citrus notes. As with all the smokestack series this beer is premium in quality and another great traditional Belgian style brew from Boulevard.

# About the Brewer

Boulevard has been a fixture in Kansas City since 1989 and is now a household name in much of the Midwest. In fact, if you're in the Midwest, you won't be able to get away from the ubiquitous (and award-winning) Unfiltered Wheat Beer. Honestly, we think a lot of Boulevard's beers are very Midwestern: not as brash as the West Coast, not as scrappy as the East Coast- just high-quality and presented simply. And it seems to have worked. Founder John McDonald originally planned for 6000 barrels of beer a year in his business plan. Now, the capacity is over 600,000 barrels. I'd say that business plan worked. The two biggest sellers are Unfiltered Wheat and Boulevard Pale Ale, but we encourage you to venture to try a few others, like the Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale, the Double Wide IPA and the Saison-Brett

# Drink this if You Like

Wheat beers, yeasty and fruity beer, Hefeweizens

# Ideal for People who Like

Fairy tales, Midwestern values, Belgian (but not really, Dutch) values

# Drink While You Are

Making the best of a bad situation, making lemonade out of lemons.

# Pair With

Citrus summer salad, Salmon, Grilled chicken, Veggie Burger.

alcohol.name: Duvel
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-Duvel_6868.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Four generations of the Moortgat family have brought together Pilsner malts, Bohemian hops, and a unique yeast strain to create this intense, aromatic and beguiling ale. This Belgian favourite is best enjoyed chilled (40 - 50 F) with discerning friends or good-looking strangers.

# What you should know

After bottling, Duvel is bottle-conditioned by adding additional yeast, and the bottles are allowed to rest in the warm brewery cellars. The yeast goes crazy, creating that high alcohol content- but then the bottles are moved to the cold, where the yeast activity slows and the fermentation completes, leaving a crisp, light taste. The name of the beer comes from the Flemish word for "Devil"

# The Boys' Take

Bubbly like champagne but smelling a lot like Belgian yeast, Duvel is lip-smackingly crisp and dry without a lot of bitterness at all

# About the Brewer

Duvel is a Belgian mega-brewer that actually now owns a few American craft brewers. However, since establishment in 1871, they seem to have used their power for niceness instead of evil. The Moortgat family actually started the brewery on their farm, and during WWI, they came into contact with English ales. They liked these so much that head brewer Albert journeyed across Britain until he found a Scottish strain that Brewery Moortgat still uses to this day. After four generations, the Moortgat grandchildren decided to take Duvel across the world and expand its reach- and we're glad you can get it at BrewPublik World Headquarters!

# Drink if you Like

Belgians, Pilseners, Saisons

# Ideal for People who Like

Champagne, cellars, Belgium, family farms

# Drink While You Are

Impressing at a dinner party

alcohol.name: Gonzo Imperial Porter
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Like Hunter S. Thompson...Gonzo Imperial Porter is deep and complex. This turbo charged version of the Road Dog Porter is mysteriously dark with a rich malty body, intense roasted flavors, and a surprisingly unique hop kick. With Gonzo weighing in at 9.2% ABV, it will bite you in the ass if you don't show it the proper respect.

# What You Should Know

All dark malts in this one, creating the smoky, dark chocolate flavor. Whereas many porters will use a base of paler/lighter malts to add some sweetness, but this is straight darkness.

# The Boy's Take

Ever had a good cognac? Roasty and boozy? We don't say this about a lot of beers, but that's kinda the taste we got here. It's very dark and rich and then has a hoppy bite at the end.

# About the Brewer

Ok, so the Flying Dog guys from Maryland are a little off their rocker. They take the craft beer stereotypes to their extremes, with loud branding, double-entendre names and goofy titles. But look past the goofiness and you'll see a really high-quality brewer. The founder came up with the outrageous name of Flying Dog in Pakistan of all places. Originally a Colorado brewery, the beer is now made really close by in Frederick, MD.

# Drink this if You Like

Porters, stouts, imperial stouts

# Ideal for People who Like

Hunter S Thompson, fear and loathing, Hennessey, Kanye

# Drink While You Are

Ballin to the walls, doing things that will forever stay in a certain city

# Pair With

Mushrooms, smoked meats, bbq, chili, hard cheese, chocolate, coffee desserts
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-4001_011d5_sm.jpeg

alcohol.name: Matilda
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-372_7ff05_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Matilda is made with a rare yeast that suggests a fruity and spicy flavor. There is complex maltiness balanced with a profuse amount of hops.

# What you should know

This beer is bottle conditioned with additional yeast added after bottling, but overall it's a pretty simple beer. The brewer uses beet sugar to feed the yeast after it's inserted in the bottles. This beer will continue developing for up to 5 years.

# The Boy's Take

Chalk this one up to smell's worse than it's bite… crack it open and we got hit with a blast of all sorts of sweet and fragrant aromas- but the taste is quite a bit drier, maybe even a little bit smoky. She finishes sweet though. Sweet Matilda.

# About the Brewer

Goose Island is Chicago's microbrewery, launched in 1988 by founder John Hall, just returned from a European tour. More than just making good craft beer, Hall advocated for it, helping bring consciousness of this new revolution to one of the US's largest cities. This meant growth, and by 1995, it was time for another brewery. Along the way, Hall had built smaller pilot beer labs and 143,000 sqft of barrel space for barrel-aging beers. This was revolutionary, and it got Goose Island its name, especially for the Bourbon Country Barrel-Aged Stout (released once a year on Black Friday and notorious for creating long lines far from the shopping malls). But eventually there was a cap to the growth, and Annheiser-Busch came calling. Yes, Goose Island has been owned by A-B for several years and that has meant… a lot more Goose Island. Most would agree, the quality of the beer is still top-notch, you just can get Goose Island in a lot more places, thanks to A-B. And there's nothing wrong with that.

# Drink this if You Like

Dubbels, Trippels, Saisons

# Ideal for People who Like

Geese, Golden Eggs, Barrels, Not judging books by their covers

# Drink While You Are

At home in your library, looking out over Lake Michigan, catching a Cubs game

# Pair With

Mussels (and other fresh shellfish), pork belly, Rind Cheeses

alcohol.name: Sofie
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-6807_c6456_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Fermented with wild yeasts and aged in wine barrels with orange peel, Sofie is a tart, dry, sparkling ale. A subtle, spicy white pepper note, a hint of citrus from the orange peel and a creamy vanilla finish make Sofie an intriguing choice for Champagne drinkers and beer drinkers who are fond of Belgian Saisons.

# What you should know

This beer is bottle conditioned with additional yeast added after bottling, but overall it's a pretty simple beer. Farmhouse Ales were originally brewed by famers to attract the best farm hands. This is named for the Granddaughter of Goose Islands founder and will continue developing for up to 5 years.

# The Boy's Take

This effervescent farmhouse ale is crisp with notes of fresh pear. While it is light in body it has a wonderful complexity. An excellent example of a Belgian beer that's made in the US!

alcohol.name: La Fin Du Monde
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-6988_a1ad3_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The end of the world. The excellence of triple fermentation through a blend of special yeasts gives this malt beverage an exquisitely robust flavor of exceptional refinement.

# What you should know

As Unibroue is found of mentioning, La Fin du Monde has won more beer festival medals than any other Canadian beer. Like most Belgian ales, the yeast added after bottling will continue to refine the beer. Hold on to it for 3 years for the best possible taste!

# The Boy's Take

Pour this one straight into the bottom of your glass to really let the yeast and medley of flavors play together! Although this smells like it will be pretty fruity, especially cirtrusy, it actually drinks pretty smoothly and ends very crisp and bubbly! It will remind you of a lager, but with a lot more going on, we think.

# About the Brewer

Unibroue, in the countryside of Quebec, was the first North American brewery to adapt Belgian Trappist style brewing, and it has paid off. Since being founded in 1992, demand for the Trappist brews has only grown, and Unibroue was purchased first by iconic Canadian brewer Sleeman and then Sleeman was purchased by the mega-brewery Sapporo from Japan. Paul Arnott, the brewmaster, has been trained in monastic brewing tradition and came over straight from Belgium in 2001.

# Drink this if You Like

Trippels, Pale Ales, Light Belgians and Pilseners

# Ideal for People who Like

Prepping or eagerly awaiting the apocalypse

# Drink While You Are

Avoiding the Four Horsemen, deserving of a reward on a warm day

# Pair With

La Fin du Monde stands up well to salty, full-bodied foods such as blue cheese or salty seafood (mussels, salmon), along with game or sausage

alcohol.name: Maudite
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

In November 1992 Maudite (the damned one), was the first strong beer to be distributed in Quebec grocery stores. Maudite is a mahogany-colored, rich-tasting premium beer that has a distinctive, complex taste. Because of the warmth it releases, this strong character beer must be served cool but not cold.
Maudite has a typically Quebecois name that is reminiscent of the legend of the Chasse-Galerie (the legend of the Flying Canoe). Legend has it that a group of lumberjacks struck a deal with the devil to fly home in their canoes, guided by Satan himself, to make it home in time for Christmas.

# What you should know

We guess there is lot of Satanic lore in Quebec- Unibroue's Trois Pistoles is a beer named after a deal cut with the devil as well. This beer is also great for aging, with 5-8 years the ideal age. Over time, the flavors will become smoother and richer.

# The Boy's Take

Perfect for a winter day, we taste a little bit of plum here, followed by some solid malts and just the hint of spice at the end. It will leave you wanting more.

# About the Brewer

Unibroue, in the countryside of Quebec, was the first North American brewery to adapt Belgian Trappist style brewing, and it has paid off. Since being founded in 1992, demand for the Trappist brews has only grown, and Unibroue was purchased first by iconic Canadian brewer Sleeman and then Sleeman was purchased by the mega-brewery Sapporo from Japan. Paul Arnott, the brewmaster, has been trained in monastic brewing tradition and came over straight from Belgium in 2001.

# Drink this if You Like

Trippels, Quads, Strong Belgian Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Lumberjacks, the Devil, Plums, Complicated things

# Drink While You Are

Up the river in a canoe without a paddle, bringing one up from your beer cellar

# Pair With

Gruyere, Spicy dishes, Tomatoes, Grilled Meat, Crème Brulee, Pasta

alcohol.name: Trois Pistoles
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Strong Belgian type ale similar to a Port wine. Is as dark as can be, mellow in taste with an aroma of ripe fruits. It can be compared to an old porto and is brewed from well roasted malt.

# What you should know

Trois Pistoles is named after a legend of a small town who recruited Satan (!)- appearing in the form of a black horse- to help them build their village church. This horse, although strong, could not be controlled and the town never finished their church building. Learn something new everyday. But for the record, we are BrewPublik would likely not recommend getting the Devil to build your church. Just doesn't seem like it would work out.

# The Boy's Take

Trois Pistoles is a beer to savor- very full-bodied and chock full of fruit flavor, this beer is well-carbonated but not for quick-drinking. It's rich and sweet and quite enjoyable.

# About the Brewer

Unibroue, in the countryside of Quebec, was the first North American brewery to adapt Belgian Trappist style brewing, and it has paid off. Since being founded in 1992, demand for the Trappist brews has only grown, and Unibroue was purchased first by iconic Canadian brewer Sleeman and then Sleeman was purchased by the mega-brewery Sapporo from Japan. Paul Arnott, the brewmaster, has been trained in monastic brewing tradition and came over straight from Belgium in 2001.

# Drink this if You Like

Trippels, Strong Belgian Ales, Stouts

# Ideal for People who Like

Ancient French Canadian legends, monks

# Drink While You Are

On the verge of deciding to try out hockey,

# Pair With

Chocolate desserts, fruit, rich cheeses
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-4045_3d373_sm.jpeg

alcohol.name: IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Our India Pale Ale exhibits a complex hop aroma, largely due to the generous usage of Cascade and Centennial hops, as well as a subtle malt character from the various malts used to achieve the wonderful balance exhibited in a world-class IPA. San Diego has become world renown for the wonderful and flavorful beers produced here – and India Pale Ales are no exception. Our national award winning interpretation of the style reflects both the history of IPA and the American variation of this distinct beverage. We hope you enjoy it!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Imperial IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Award Winning beers, Wonder Bread

# Drink While You Are

Sitting down, Missioning

# Pair With

Traditional Mexican Fare, Grilled Meats

alcohol.name: Grapefruit Sculpin
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-285658_5908f_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The Sculpin IPA is a testament to our humble beginnings as Home Brew Mart. Founded in 1992, the Mart continues to be a catalyst for the San Diego brewing scene, setting the trend for handcrafted ales. Inspired by our customers, employees and brewers, the Sculpin IPA is bright with aromas of apricot, peach, mango and lemon. Its lighter body also brings out the crispness of the hops. This delicious Ballast Point Ale took a Bronze Medal at the 2007 Great American Beer Festival in the Pro Am category. The Sculpin fish has poisonous spikes on its fins that can give a strong sting. Ironically, the meat from a Sculpin is considered some of the most tasty. Something that has a sting but tastes great, sounds like a Ballast Point India Pale Ale. Our Grapefruit Sculpin is the latest take on our signature IPA. Some may say there are few ways to improve Sculpin’s unique flavor, but the tart freshness of grapefruit perfectly complements our IPA’s citrusy hop character. Grapefruit’s a winter fruit, but this easy-drinking ale tastes like summer.

# What you should know

This beer is hoppy, but doesn’t rely on brute force to bring across the delicious.  The use of lighter, soft malts (only four varieties) leads to a light body that really showcases the bright hop taste.  Unusually, hops are actually added during the mashing process, to give a nice oily feel and taste.

# The Boys' Take

There’s a reason a lot of people will say this is literally the best American IPA!  The hops are allowed free reign to really show themselves off, and there is so much flavor- mango, grapefruit, pine.  Treat this like Skittles.  Taste the rainbow.  

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers.  Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene.  Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world.  As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out.  Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born.   Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea.

# Drink this if You Like

Fruity or tropical IPAs, IPAs in general

# Ideal for People who Like

The tropics, fishing, the sunny climes of San Diego

# Drink While You Are

Enduring a brutal winter and wishing you were in San Diego, dealing with a hot summer and wishing you were in San Diego

# Pair With

Tropical savory foods (think flavored by coconut), Jerk Chicken, Tropical fruit

alcohol.name: Burton Baton
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-6105_5a13b_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The elusive brew is made from pilsner malt and amber malt with an original gravity of 26.5?P, yielding an 11% abv. It's hopped with Warrior and Glacier varieties. Primary fermentation takes place in open vessels using two yeast strains, one American and one English. For added complexity, the beer is conditioned on barrel staves of French Oak for four months before being dry hopped with Glacier at the rate of a half-pound per barrel. This elixir is then blended 50/50 with 90 Minute IPA. After blending, the beer will measure 80 IBU and 10% abv.

# What you should know

So this beer is actually a mix of the Dogfish Head 90-Minute IPA recipe and a Glacier-hopped amber cocktail that is aged on French Oak barrels. Glacier hops are a variant of the original English-style hops, but there here to contribute more flavor than bitterness, as the 90-Minute IPA brings more than enough of that to the table.

# The Boys' Take

Imagine the deliciousness of Dogfish Head 90-minute, but with a huge boozy, malty base to play with,. This one starts big and boozy and bitter before finishing up with some really interesting caramel and vanilla notes. This is something you've got to try

# About the Brewer

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role. Founder Sam Calagione started the brewery in Milton, DE in 1995 and now spends much time on television discussing the craft beer industry. In fact, at least on the east coast, it's hard to avoid DFH- there's a hotel, a tv show and even sausages for heaven's sake! But they do make amazing beer, often with unique flavor combinations and even stranger names. 90-Minute IPA is the more extreme version of one of Dogfish's signature brews (the 60-minute IPA). If you like this beer, try the 60-minute for session drinking or the Burton Baton for a full experience.

# Drink If you Like

Big Belgians, barrel-aged beer, stouts, Imperial IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

The fact that we said Big Belgians above, sipping beer, everything oaked

# Drink While You Are

Sitting in a big leather chair, smoking a cigar

# Pair With

Toasted nuts, peanut sauce, spicy food

alcohol.name: Flesh & Blood IPA
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description:  

An honest to goodness India Pale Ale brewed with a bevy of real citrus including orange peel, lemon flesh & blood orange juice.

# What you should know: 

Tropical fruit included as an ingredient in IPAs is sooooo the rage in 2016.  The sugars in the fruit provide extra food for the yeast but still stay around, no longer sweet but still flavorful.

# The Boys’ Take: 

If there’s a more refreshing summer beer, we’d like to hear it. Of course, tons of fruit and pith- it almost feels like there is grapefruit pulp in there.  And there are still hops, don’t worry

# About the Brewer:

# Drink If you Like:

alcohol.name: Falco
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-_318741_3538d15cd961d82c8dc44483d64e.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

What makes a great leader? First of all a perfectly balanced blend of qualities, the ability to stand out, be authoritative without overpowering. Show courage and endurance, you will lead the way and set the standards. Very important, be appealing and refreshing to the people. This stereotypical portrait applies whether referring to politics, religion or maybe even this outstanding IPA

# What You Should Know

The name of this brew comes from the hops used, called Falconer's Flight- a blend of 7 different varieties of Pacific Northwest hops. This leads to a unique flavor profile and is just as simple as dropping one variety in the brew. Time-saver!

# The Boys' Take

On the softer, easy-going side of IPAs, Falco has a decently light body that really showcases the fruity hops included here. There is bitterness at the end, but it's not biting. The caramel maltiness of this IPA is a little more prominent than some others.

# About the Brewer

Evil Twin is unique. It's a gypsy brewery, meaning it develops the recipes, but uses breweries across the world to actually make the beer. This means it isn't committed to a solid list of beers that it makes at its brewery. It bounces around from one to the another, making a wide range of different special releases, along with a few that they release year-round. Check out their website ( [www.eviltwin.dk](http://www.eviltwin.dk)) - I mean, there are tons of beers here. It's made in the states, but marketed like an import (and priced like it, too). Quite an interesting brewery. Low Life is brewed in Connecticut, in case your were wondering. Check out their other beers in the import aisle!

# Drink if You Like

IPAs, English Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Falcons, the thrill of the hunt, the Danish

# Drink While You Are

Nursing a bird of prey gently back to health so it can fly free again

# Pair With

Havarti, spicy dishes

alcohol.name: Hipster Ale
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Perhaps you heard of a worldwide beer-movement
that tributes favorite hipster neighbourhoods across the globe. First
came Istedgade, Copenhagen then Södermalm, Stockholm followed by
Williamsburg, New York and Shoreditch, London accompanied by Trastevere,
Rome & last El Raval, Barcelona. If you feel excluded because you’re hip
but your city is not, this cutting-edge, ‘hip without borders’ pale ale
is an homage to you – the global hipster. Cheers!

# The Boys’ Take

Usually known for doing everything to the extreme,
Evil Twin has really toned it down with this really solid pale ale. With
a great balance of bready malts and floral and citrus hops this is a
great beer for any occasion. 

# About the Brewer

Evil Twin is unique. It’s a gypsy brewery, meaning
it develops the recipes, but uses breweries across the world to actually
make the beer. This means it isn’t committed to a solid list of beers
that it makes at its brewery. It bounces around from one to the another,
making a wide range of different special releases, along with a few that
they release year-round. Check out their website
([www.eviltwin.dk](http://www.eviltwin.dk)) - I mean, there are tons of
beers here. It’s made in the states, but marketed like an import (and
priced like it, too). Quite an interesting brewery. Low Life is brewed
in Connecticut, in case your were wondering. Check out their other beers
in the import aisle!

# Drink if You Like

IPAs, Pale Ales, West Coast Style IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Stuff that other people don’t think are
cool yet.

# Drink While You Are

Being ironic, wearing a scarf, being “unique”

# Pair With

Burgers, Buffalo wings, BBQ.

alcohol.name: Raging Bitch Belgian IPA
alcohol.untappdString: Raging Bitch Belgian IPA (Flying Dog Brewery)
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-5756_58e81_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The American IPA hoppines or Belgian funk of Raging Bitch can be brought out with food. Flavor notes: Sweet malt body contrasted with pine and grapefruit hop flavors and exotic fruit yeast notes.

# What you should know

Flying Dog's bottle art is by done by famous artist Ralph Steadman. The Gonzo art is most associated with the writing of Hunter S. Thompson.

# The Boy's Take

A well balanced IPA disguises its high ABV with a solid malt back bone that balances its hop profile.

# About the Brewer

Ok, so the Flying Dog guys from Maryland are a little off their rocker. They take the craft beer stereotypes to their extremes, with loud branding, double-entendre names and goofy titles. But look past the goofiness and you'll see a really high-quality brewer. The founder came up with the outrageous name of Flying Dog in Pakistan of all places. Originally a Colorado brewery, the beer is now made really close by in Frederick, MD.

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian Pale Ale's, Pale Ales, IPA's

# Ideal for People who Like

The bohemian writer lifestyle, dual citizenship.

# Drink While You Are

Wearing lederhosen, watching Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas, On an acid trip.

# Pair With

Wasabi ginger, jerk, Caju, or cayenne, tangy cheese with fruit, dark chocolate

alcohol.name: Simtra Triple IPA
alcohol.untappdString: Simtra Triple IPA (Knee Deep Brewing Company)
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-SimtraTrippleIPA_93848.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Simtra Triple IPA delivers a punch in the face with its very danky hop aroma derived from Simcoe and Citra hops. You wanted more hops you got them.

# The Boys' Take

A really hoppy brew from the masters of the IPA Knee Deep. This hop monster clocks in at 131 IBUs. If you're on the quest for an ever hoppier IPA this is the next rung on the ladder.

# About the Brewer

In the fall of 2010 while tasting some of their home brew Jeremy and Jerry Moore decided to get into the premium craft beer business and they wanted to go more than just "Knee Deep" in the market. They started with contract brewing their beer (having other breweries brew your beer in their facility. They currently have their own space and re cranking out some award winning IPAs.

# Drink If You Like

Double IPAs, IPAs, Imperial IPAs

# Ideal For People Who Like

Wading, Maniacal cartoons

# Drink While You Are

Fly fishing a California trout stream, Going the extra mile again.

# Food Pairings

Pad Thai, Red Thai Curry, Buffalo wings,

alcohol.name: Shipwrecked
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

A style of beer curiously born on the foggy shores
of Father Junipero Serra’s first founding mission. Our own vigorous
entry is one rebellious IPA, quick on the trigger, and brimming with a
bounty of hop ingenuity. This is a big, bold, brazen beer, a restless
vision of a new America.

# The Boy’s Take

This is a very west coasty double IPA. Plenty of
hops and malt perfectly blending malt sweetness and citrusy goodness. If
you haven’t tried this one you’re in for a treat!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and “mission” was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each. We recommend the
Dark Seas Imperial Stout and also their Pils and Helles lagers.

# Drink this if You Like

Double IPAs, Imperial IPA, IPA

# Ideal for People who Like

Shipwrecks, architecture

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying 24/7 sun, sailing the open seas,
channeling your inner conquistador

# Pair With

Chimichangas, Pad Thai, Mango Chutney.

alcohol.name: Midas Touch
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-dfhMidaTouch.jpg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Midas Touch Golden Elixir is a beverage based on the residue found on the drinking vessels in King Midas' tomb. Our recipe highlights the known ingredients of barley, white Muscat grapes, honey and saffron. Somehwere between a beer, wine and mead, this smooth, dry ale will please with Chardonnay or I.P.A. drinker alike.

# What you should know

Dogfish Head is a little nutty. The brewery has been working with biomolecular archaeologist Dr. Patrick McGovern to research ancient brewing habits. Well, when Dr. McGovern worked with the team that uncovered the tomb of King Midas, Unbelievably, there was still residue from the king's last feast on vessels buried with him. Well of course, that means it was time to copy the recipe! What resulted from this craziness is Midas Touch

# The Boys' Take

What a fascinating beer! It's sweet, tart, and unlike many beers, actually tastes a little like grapes. The first sips taste of white wine, followed by some malty toasted flavor, maybe even some strawberry jam? I mean, if you're going to drink like a king, might as well drink like King Midas!

# About the Brewer

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role. Founder Sam Calagione started the brewery in Milton, DE in 1995 and now spends much time on television discussing the craft beer industry. In fact, at least on the east coast, it's hard to avoid DFH- there's a hotel, a tv show and even sausages for heaven's sake! But they do make amazing beer, often with unique flavor combinations and even stranger names.

# Drink this if You Like

White wine, pale beers, Belgian beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Science! Archaeology, Ancient Greece

# Drink While You Are

Debating the classics, enjoying book club

# Pair With

Asian dishes, risotto, curry, baked fish + chicken

alcohol.name: Fireside Chat
alcohol.label: https://untappd.akamaized.net/site/beer_logos/beer-7468_b8213_sm.jpeg
alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Like FDR's Depression-Era Radio Addresses, which were like a kick in the butt and a hug at the same time, our Fireside Chat is a subtle twist on the traditional seasonal brew. We begin with a rich, dark, English-style ale and then we improvise with spices until we know we have a beer worth sharing with the nation. Celebrating the right to be original.

# What You Should Know

Winter warmers are generally characterized by big malt flavor, and a wide variety of spices (more a feature of American interpretations rather than the original English style). They also typically carry higher alcohol content. Fireside Chat is brewed with a delicious medley of spices and also cocoa nibs to give a slight chocolate flavor.

# The Boys' Take

Ask Zach about this beer, and he'll tell you it's dope! An office favorite, Fireside Chat is rich, but without being overpowering and the mix of spices is just delightful.

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious. They just have the advantage of pulling it off maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

Dark ales, Winter warmers, Strong ales

# Ideal for People who Like

World War II, Christmas spices, mulled cider, a cozy blanket

# Drink While You Are

Wanting to be Zach's friend, listening to the radio

# Pair With

An aperitif, dessert

# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float
